description:
Wow, what a pleasant surprise.

Laverne N. and I randomly booked a reservation at Ijji Sushi for my belated birthday dinner and came in with low expectations. It ended up being one of my top omakase experiences in SF!

We were served by chef Alex, who was extremely knowledgeable about each cut of fish (including, but not limited to, origins/history, why the texture of the fish is the way it is, and fun facts). It was complete package: dinner and a course in everything related to sushi.

I even took some notes:
- The island of Shikoku has large waves, so the fish from this area do not have any fat (since they need to swim/work harder against the waves).
- Salmon from the ocean has more fat, whereas trout from the river has more flavor.
- Baby fish is more delicate and has less flavor.
- Traditional Edomae style sushi from the 16th-18th century used cured fish and no garnishes.

Will be back for another sushi lesson soon!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
A very beautiful counter and an intimate room. The service was perfect, almost performative. The chefs were deliberate in their movement, and their work was choreographed, essentially. The servers were that rare combination of attentive and almost invisible. No one was trying to be plucky or cute, just hustling to make your experience a good one. Very good sake and wine pairings.

Now the reason this review is only for 3 stars is the food, which was surprisingly-mediocre for the price tag. Ijjji goes a long way on supposedly serving authentic Japanese, but most of our tasting menu ate bland and boring-textured. The exceptions were the green soybean cake in bonito broth, which had an elevated matzo ball soup -vibe, and their seaweed with grapes & vinegar mozuku. The other dishes could use more acid and crunch -- there was way too much unctuous umami, and not enough sharpness & contrast.

Their fish sourcing is clearly top notch, but some combination of handling, aging, cutting, or saucing left the fish boring. For a place that prides itself on sushi, we should not come away liking their vegetarian dishes the most. Their tamago & shrimp tasted freezer-burned. We could not finish the miso ice cream, which was just a sugar bomb. I wonder if they are over-reaching?
author: Ben G.

description:
This was an exquisitely intimate sushi restaurant! We sat at the bar and had excellent and attentive service. 

The Inada and Sakura Masu, as well as the Kasugodai was exceptional. But one of the most stand out dishes was a delicious silky seaweed with cherry tomatoes starter. 

They also made a point to ask what we liked and didn't like to keep on file for us in the future...

Perfect special occasion destination!
author: natalie b.

description:
Ijji Sushi is definitely one of the top omokase joints in San Francisco. First of all the front of this business doesn't make it obvious that it's a nice sushi joint--look for the blue cloth hanging over the entrance. Secondly, the small/intimate dining room makes the experience feel higher quality (extreme opposite of a churn and burn AYCE sushi buffet). Thirdly and most importantly, the food is amazing. There's no need to go into detail about the food when you know it's going to be good and you just need to let the magic occur. With utter certainty, everything you put into your mouth here is worth a million bucks. Feast your eyes on the pictures I posted and don't worry, those goosebumps will go away in about 5 minutes.

My personal omokase restaurant pro-tips (in general, not just here at Ijji):
1) Try to book early enough to get a seat at the bar to enjoy the chefs in their element creating edible art.
2) My wife always laughs at me for this, but close your eyes after putting the nigiri in your mouth. Focus on the flavors and let it melt away on your taste buds. Seriously, I know you might think it's awkward but you're not just paying for some fish and rice, you're here for a delicious handcrafted morsel with lots of energy put into it so pay it some respect and focus all your tasting concentration back on it!
3) In my honest opinion there's no need for ever doing the alcohol pairing--just enjoy the fish and get some drinks before or after!
author: Marlon T.

description: Phenomenal Omakase experience at Ijji Sushi last night. Exquisitely delicious, fresh and authentic. I will certainly be back!
author: Trang Ashley P.

description:
- Ordered: Omakase (it's the only thing you can order here). The menu changes everyday depending on their fish shipment. 

- Food: The flavors were flawless. The 4 cooked starters were very delicate and simply amazing. The 13 pieces of nigiri were super fresh and flavors were paired perfectly with the golden eye snapper, cherry salmon, & uni being my favorite 
There's a small a la Carte menu they give you before the last piece so I ordered two more and my brother orders two as well. We ended the meal with a red miso soup and a miso ice cream made with that soup which I could've ate 10 scoops of 

- Service: Top notch. The chef who was serving us was so polite and we had a great convo 

- Ambiance : modern traditional. There are only 6 seats at the bar and 3 small tables 

- Price: $145/pp for omakase 

- Additional comments: must make reservation
author: Chelsea H.

description:
The food is spectacular, the price not quite. But then again, I think most omakase spots in SF are on the pricier side. Perhaps it just seemed extreme to me because I've had sushi in LA/OC of similar quality at a much more affordable price. 

Don't get me wrong though - I loved every single bite and the intimate dining experience was exciting and new for me. It's just for that price, it really hurts lol. For five people and a bottle of sake, the total came out to be a little over $1000. 

The service was excellent! The staff are attentive, polite, and take time to explain the dishes to you. The progression and pace of the dishes were good too. The whole experience lasted about 2 and a half hours. 

My top dishes of the night were the shima aji (yellowtail), hiyashi somen (wheat noodles in chilled bonito broth), madai kobujime (red sea bream), hotate (sea scallop), uni tofu, tamago atsuyaki (egg custard with blue shrimp).
author: Natalie L.

description:
holy 19 course omakase, batman!
ijji sushi elevates the omakase experience to another level. it's straight jiro style, one piece of sushi at a time.
over these past few years, i've been minimizing my sushi consumption because i feel guilty contributing to the rampant overfishing, but man, eating at ijji was amazing and i'd do it again.
my favorite was the suke akami, a lean cut of bluefin tuna (and i'm not a big tuna fan).
sit at the bar!
author: Jess K.

description:
Ok not sure how to explain this place: inconspicuous, small, quiet and great quality fish! Everything was well thought from the appetizer to the 13 nigiri fish. Unique pieces and combinations of textures made by the chef. 
Though pricy at $150 per person it's worth it for a special occasion.
author: Magda C.

description:
Very good and the design of the restaurant with its long sushi bar is impressive. I like the hand rolls better at Sushi Pier but the food and service at Ijji make it well worth the visit. I look forward to my next visit. 
Merritt Weisinger
author: Susan H.

description:
a lot of the allure of this restaurant is how small and intimate it feels. people have mentioned how it only has a few seats and that really adds to the ambiance. sitting at the bar, you have a clear view of the chefs preparing their plates - you feel involved in the meal. i highly recommend waiting for the bar experience - you see the finesse in the preparation, and the staff is very welcoming of questions from anyone even if they are novice. the staff is so wonderful. friendly, pleasant, professional. 

the platting of the omakase is very minimal, in a good way. it allows you to focus (in the right way) on the pieces of sushi being presented. the presentation is clear and simple. 

the meal itself is delightful - there is more experience and passion with the chefs at ijji. all the fish is fresh, all the bites balanced and flavorful. one of the most common issues i have with omakase is that the chefs put way to much wasabi under the fish. i've never understood why you would want to overpower the taste of the fish, rice, sauces and other things with just one flavor. At ijji, this is NOT the case. there is a perfect balance of flavors. 

great place for a nice evening for getting to know people. not cheap, but worth every penny. you're paying almost double other omakase's but really really worth it
author: Jonathan Q.

description:
Ijji is so underrated in SF's omakase scene!

My girlfriend and I would sometimes walk past Ijji's minimalistic storefront and wonder what was inside. Once we found out via Yelp that it's an omakase place, we had to add it to our list. She made the reservation for us almost a month in advance, and off we went. 

We sat at the bar with two other foodie couples, one sushi chef per couple. As the meal progressed, it kinda turned into a party even though we were strangers. I highly recommend requesting bar seating if you want to mingle with other patrons and interact with the chef. Our chef was a little shy but super nice and shared a lot of interesting tidbits about each type of fish and the preparation method as he went along. 

Our chef prepared and placed each course in front of us one by one, for a total of 23 items (5 appetizers, 12 nigiri pieces, a palate cleanser, a small bite, miso soup, and finally dessert). Everything was so delicious but a few of the standouts for me were the appetizers, uni (a mixture from Hokkaido and Santa Barbara which is the best uni I've ever had), and the o-toro (the fattiest and most buttery fatty tuna I've ever had), and the housemade yuzu ice cream. My only complaint about the ice cream is that there wasn't enough of it. Towards the end of the meal, we received a menu of their supplements which you can decline if you're full. We opted for additional pieces of o-toro because it was just that good. 

For what it's worth, my girlfriend was born in Japan and spent the first 12 years of her life there, and she gives Ijji a solid A. She says we will definitely be back!
author: Olivia V.

description:
The eel, tamago, and uni with tofu were my favorite dishes. I usually don't like tamago but this had the perfect savory but sweet flavor. I loved it. 

The uni tofu is a obvious WOW. You can tell it will be good before you even try it. 

The eel was mouth watering. That was the OMFG piece for me. It was super tender and just melted in my mouth. It may be my absolute favorite piece he whole night. 

Everything else was good but with so many other omakase style restaurants, it's hard not to compare. There were a few dishes I've had at another restaurant which was better such as the marinated seaweed shooters and toro hand roll that are far more superior (feel free to look at my other post for that review. The restaurant starts with an H). The other dishes didn't have as much flavor as I would liked. I felt like they could had marinated or glazed a bit more. The clam soup was pretty bland and the clam seemed over cooked. And the first piece of sashimi was chewy. 

Their service was really good but on a Wednesday, there were only 2 groups there. It didn't seem like anyone booked the 8pm seating either. So it was definitely a slow day.
author: Karen L.

description:
Had an amazing anniversary dinner here. What a memorable meal! The service was impeccable and the food & wine pairing were perfect. 

Sit at the bar if you can--It was really fun to watch the chefs at work and interact with them. I was stuffed but the bf left a little hungry still, so maybe don't come here when you are starving if you have a big appetite. 

Each of the 19 courses was a work of art. Everything tasted excellent, although we were most blown away by the wagyu beef so we ordered more. They wrapped up our menu and a card for us to take home after our meal, which was a thoughtful gesture. 

2 seating times only--6 or 8:30 pm. Be sure to make a reservation!
author: Joyce H.

description:
Sushi was just ok.
Customer service is great went it's not busy.
They need to hire more staff at such times.
author: Sarah H.

description:
New favorite omakase spot for us. 

+ Good ambiance, feels refined but simple
+ Unique pieces, lots of aged and marinated fish - nice texture that I haven't had before!
~ Fairly fast paced, you'll be out in 2 hours
+ Great waitstaff and very attentive, knowledgeable about the fish and where it's from
+ Worth coming back to - staff tracks what pieces you've had previously!
author: Dustin H.

description:
The bar seating is the full experience and it'll let you see where the action happens. The chef cuts and prepares each dish in front of you and also presents each dish to make sure that you fully understood each bite. The tasting menu is also seasonal, just to make sure that you get the best bites each day.

The menu is also setup in a way where the flavor goes from light to heavy. The porportion is pretty good, but don't go there real hungry. It's all about the experience and the taste, not just about filling up your stomach. The restaurant acknowledge any food allergies and tries their best to accommodate them, but you have to let them know ahead of time so they can prepare a special menu. Very thoughtful and nice experience! Will definitely go there again and recommend to friends.
author: king w.

description: Ijji is quiet and intimate, and also perfect for a special occasion. I booked dinner here for my birthday a few weeks ago and the first thing that struck me was their interior.  Their luxurious sushi bar table and the wood paneling is incredible. While there were a few pieces of fish that I wasn't overly keen on, the one thing I absolutely loved was their tamago that's served at the end. I've made comments about how I've had delicious tamagos at other places in the past, but this one really blew me away. The freshness of the fish was certainly there and I loved the Zuke Toro and also the Sakura Masu. It's a little pricey and I'm certain that you could have comparable experiences at other sushi places in San Francisco.  If you happen to find yourself with a cool $145/person, this would be a great place to go to.
author: Lisa I.

description:
One of the best Omakase places I have eaten at. Each dish was spot on, the fish here is the top quality and are fresh from Japan  I loved the thoughtfulness of presentation ! The service from the main Chef Alex and Ryan owner were professional and super attentive! Each dish was introduced warmly and swiftly.
Would definitely recommend checking this place out! It's a total gem
author: Katie E.

description:
3.5 stars. Not as good as ju-ni or Omakase but I walked out satisfied.

Pros:
+ very fresh fish! The toros were heavenly and totally melted in mouth. Chu toro, o-toro, wild barracuda, scallop, tamago, and akamutsu were my favorite pieces.

+ I don't like octopus but the braised one from Hokkaido that they serve here was pretty life changing. I actually loved it!

+ the sawara (Spanish mackerel) starter was also very tasty and perfectly cooked 

+ good value. 19 courses for $135 - we were so stuffed after the meal! 

Con:
- our sushi chef sort of scolded us for chatting with the chef next to him since each chef is suppose to be only dedicated to who they are serving. I get that but ours was the one cutting fish so he basically looked down the entire time and it wasn't easy to just ask him stuff. If you're looking for an interactive experience, don't expect that here. Kusakabe and Ju-ni have much warmer and friendly vibes.

- the fish was great but rice was so disappointing - it was pretty grainy and contrasted with the delicious fish. 

- our sushi pieces felt like they might fall apart when picked up, so I'm guessing the rice isn't sticky enough.

- unlike other top sushi places I've been, they are strict and hesitant about letting you swap out anything on the menu you don't eat. 

Service was good and overall we liked the meal, but it definitely wouldn't be our top choice to splurge on for sushi.
author: Sophia H.

description: Made reservation for birthday dinner 6 weeks ago. Emailed restaurant soon after to confirm seating. No one responded. Tried calling and no one answered. No voicemail service. Last weekend suddenly received message that restaurant had canceled our reservation. Wow thanks and now we are left with nowhere to go, as other $$$$ sushi places are fully booked. HIGHLY RECOMMEND EVERYONE TO GO SOMEWHERE ELSE FOR SPECIAL EVENTS! I will never return to Ijji.
author: Reira C.

description:
When you already have a reputation as an outstanding restaurant, what makes you better?  Attention to personal service.

No need to wax lyrical about the quality of the dining experience, other reviewers have done it and it is all true.  No, I need to give chops for how my pre-visit interaction with Ijji exceeded expectations.  Coming in from NYC the day of my reservation to dine with my son, I didn't want to leave my desire to sit at the sushi bar or his shellfish allergies to chance.  With various thoughtful email exchanges with Ryan, the Manager, not only did we establish that my son could eat uni but could not eat octopus, but we were seated front and center at the sushi bar where I could practice my sketchy Japanese with the head chef.   Everyone receives a copy of the menu for the night; my son received his personalized copy as well.

Good omokase sushi in San Francisco is plentiful; I have been to Ju-Ni as well.  Personal service like I received at Ijji however is far harder to find.  I will be back.
author: J R C.

description: I thought ijji was a very solid omakase restaurant and always thought for the longest time... who did they piss off a the Michelin Star place to have not gotten a star??? They really deserve one! They are consistently one of the highest rated omakase places and are very reasonably priced. I would rate them much higher than other places who have stars or lost stars recently. Ijji's style is more along the lines of wako, Ju-ni, and sushi hon... the type that has some marinades and smoked meats but still very focused on the flavor of the fish. I think they have great execution and I remember loving the place a lot. The amount of food is just enough to be full... probably could get a couple of extra pieces to be fully satisfied. However their prices are very reasonable for omakase in the city. I guess they lack the glitz and glam of a Michelin restaurant but food wise? On par. Also it's easy to get a reservation! I definitely recommend ijji!
author: Jocelyn K.

description: One of the best traditional nigiri omakase restaurants in SF (I've sampled Kusakabe, Miruya, Pabu, and others). The flavor pairing per nigiri was impeccable. A very no-frills shop.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Had high hope coming here since we enjoyed Saru, but this place is just okay. Small place, reservation required. Service is very good. We got the omakase, which cost about $70/person for 10 pcs of sushi + starter and we ordered some more additional sushi. We got:
Starter - asparagus with dashi and marinated clam(good)
Kanpachi/amberjack(okay)
Hallibut/hirami(okay)
Lean tuna(taste like cheap tuna)
Octopus(good)
Seabream(okay)
Trout(very good!)
Herring(very fishy aftertaste)
Salmon roe marinated(salty)
Mackerel(okay)
Chutoro(skip this, the otoro is so much better)
------ additional order:
Otoro(very good!)
Uni(good!)
Kani(very good!)
Tamago(taste like shrimp ball, but sweet. It's a bit weird)

This place is comparable to Wako, so if you like Wako you probably like this place. I wouldn't come back to both Wako and Ijji. You'll get much better foods at Ju-ni or Kusakabe!
author: Prisilia P.

description: So happy to have this place in SF.  Everything was a true delight from the happy bubbles to kick off the culinary adventure to each amazing dish (we even had to add a few more because we couldn't stop eating) to the elegant little dessert to close the experience.  Will need to book a return soon before word gets out and it will take over 6 months before a reservation is available.  Don't think I can suffer that!  Bravo to the owners!
author: Lev E.

description:
Great omakase experience. Meal is well timed (and only about an hour and a half, which is a great alternative to the trend towards 3+ hour meals). Everything is made and prepared in house, which results in fresh, full flavors.

Intimate setting with 6 seats at the bar in full view of the kitchen and 4 tables for 2 behind. 

Highlights: their Tamago is unique (made by blending together eggs, blue shrimp, white fish, mountain yam and many other ingredients) and delicious, ikura is very fresh and pure in flavor, uni tofu is silky and jammed full of taste. All of the nigiri is solid - varieties that are less common in SF (eg barracuda, wild yellowtail). 

Definite recommendation for a date night.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I tend to do a lot of research before going to a restaurant- especially fine dining. After I set up a reservation for Ijji, I began my research. I found that there are multiple "Ijji" locations throughout the US. Panicking, I thought I had signed up to eat at a chain restaurant. After additional frantic research, I realized I was safe and this restaurant had way too much character to be a chain. I digress.
Ijji is my current favorite fine dining venue of this year. It's pricey, but you get an intimate tasting experience with the chef. It's perfect for a date night, and the 19 courses make a great conversation topic.
author: Rad S.

description:
Ijji is the first SF $100+ omakase to truly live up to its hype to me. I've tried $100+ omakases at Kusakabe, Pabu, Sushi Ran, and Ichi+Ni but always left hungry and let down (and ready to flee back to Kiss Seafood, my favorite omakase spot). After a superb dinner here, I see myself returning.

The service and hushed miniature spa-retreat vibe of this spot put me in the mind of a smaller Benu: warm and attentive service rendered in a private, soothing wood-set hideout.

The 1st piece of kinmedai with grilled snapper scales immediately awed us into attention. What follows is an impressive cascade of Japanese premium fish marinated, grilled, and zested beyond many competitor's subtly and finesse. It felt, again, more like Benu than any super traditional sushi place, but it's unmistakably Modern Asian and Michelin-grade San Franciscan high cuisine (rather than the gaudy cheeseball "fusion" of Nobu in Vegas / Sushi of Gari in NYC). Unlike the westernized Pabu/Sushi Ran/Ichi+Ni, it felt unmistakeable 2017 -- it assumes you already know what's authentic, and then it very slightly modifies that.

Some standouts: kinmedai, marinated chu-toro, firefly squid, striped bass with yuzu seaweed (holy heck!), and anago.

I'll admit, the freshness of 1/3 of the fish is maybe A+ instead of A+++ as you'd demand for the price (we came on the 8:30 shift on Sunday, possibly the least flattering day for sushi shops), but every piece of nigiri was so lovingly marinated, scorched, and zested with Japanese herbs that we had a hard time picking fault.

Kudos to Ijji for achieving a modern perfection without sacrificing authenticity and subtly. The sensibility is wholly Ijji's own. I will definitely be back.
author: Ken H.

description:
Wow. Ijji Sushi was one of the most exceptional dining experiences I've ever had.

My boyfriend and I both ordered the omakase, which begins with a small appetizer, before diving into several small plates of nigiri. To start, we devoured our appetizer of octopus and cooked vegetables. To follow, each plate of nigiri arrives with 2-3 pieces--a simple, balanced plate that allows you to slowly savor each bite. The selection changes nightly, but on our visit, we tried tamago atsuyaki, hotate (scallop), lean tuna, crab with crab butter, needlefish, and several more that I don't remember the names of. We finished our dinner with the Housemade Matcha and vanilla soybean ice cream... a light, refreshing finish to an exceptional meal.

I highly recommend Ijji, especially for a date night, or more intimate dinner. The interior is small and incredibly intimate, but pleasantly so, and your meal will be a truly unique experience.
author: Fiona F.

description:
Technically 3.5 Stars.

Reservation for four on a Saturday night is highly recommended. This place can only hold about a handful of people. It's quite small and tidy.

We all opted for the Omakase, which came in 10 pieces of nigiri and about two starters. I always suggest people to sit at the sushi bar for many reasons:

1) The chef will be informative about their fresh fishes. 
2) Entertaining to watch them carefully cut/slice/plate their food.
3) Get to know the chef and the restaurant better by asking question(s).

By the end of the dining experienced, I was clearly not wowed by the Omakase selections. Of the 10 pieces of nigir, I only found two of them to be exciting and delicious. The Sakura Masu (salmon) and the Hotaru ika (firefly squid). 

The four of us also ended up ordering extra nigiri and Toro was definitely melt in your mouth kind of texture.

Overall, Ijji  was good, but not great. The selection of fishes could have been better. I do give them props for an amazing service to refilling my tea and changing my teacup to a new one each time. 

I do hope you give this Japanese place a try. Cheers! 

My personal ranking in the Bay Area for Omakase:
1) Sushi Yoshizumi
2) Wako
3) Maruya 
4) Ju-ni
5) Akiko's
7) Hachi Ju Hachi
8) Kuskabe
9) Ijji
author: Owie N.

description:
This is a tasty sushi restaurant. No joke. Every single piece of sushi was crafted and cured to perfection. It looks simple, there's not a whole lot of decoration or fluff on the sushi, but the taste is consistently clean and refreshing. 

Many sushi restaurants I've been to has always had some decoration to enhance its aesthetic appeal. Where it's topped with ornamental sometimes sculptural consumables, drizzled with sauces, sprinkled with seeds, powders, or other toppings, or it may be accompanied by edible or inedible garnishes. LOOKS great for your food blog! But the taste... is not always 10/10.

At Ijji - it's not about food photography, it's about quality- it focuses on the art of curing the fish to ensure the experience from beginning to end is consistently delicious. There's not one dish throughout the omakase experience that I had to stop and think "huh, this is a bit fishy."
author: Nit A.

description:
Excellent, memorable. I was actually full after the $135 omakase! Fish quality EXTREMELY high - I liked Wako too but I think the fish at Ijji is better. The starters are very fresh and flavorful -  highlights for me were bonito and prawn cake in bonito broth. The 12 sushi courses were incredibly tasty, simple but flavor spot on. Soy cured fatty tuna, wild barracuda with sesame and shiso, and wild young snapper were highlights. I think the soy sauce use was juuuuust slightly heavy-handed for some pieces, but really did not decrease my enjoyment. Yuzu ice-cream at the end also delicious, delicate and well-balanced flavor. 

Service impeccable. Sat at the bar and loved watching the chefs work their magic. 

Recommend!!
author: Erin C.

description:
Ijji sushi served excellent quality fish! The service for us was great but the chefs weren't as well put together as traditional sushi restaurants like Nakazawa or Yasuda. Maybe because they just opened recently when we went so it felt the chefs seemed a bit disorganized. One chef would take another chefs sliced fish and converse on whose or what fish it was. 

Another thing that made me give it 4 stars is because of a particular service I witnessed. The person next to us tried to order uni but the chefs claimed they were sold out. Next thing you know, he pulls out a new box of uni and serves uni nigiris to the table behind us. The man was trying to persuade him in a nice manner to make him a piece because he flew out from NY but the chef just said "sorry, it is for tomorrow. No. Sorry." I understand where the chef is coming from to the extent that the next day is a Sunday and he needs to reserve fish because the fish market is closed. However, if it was me, I would not hesitate to make one piece for a customer who will leave happy. I guess that didn't happen to us but witnessing that left me a bit of an impression on the customer service at Ijji.

 I do recommend going there and trying it out because they do serve very fresh fish from Japan! I also liked that they made sure I get a hot cup of green tea every now and then.
author: Natalie C.

description: I would give it no star if this is an option. I booked this restaurant over a month ago for celebrating birthday and they just call me (5 days ahead the appointment day) and said that the book is cancelled since they have plumbing issue. I would understand this situation, but i will not understand that this is the only thing you said to me. You didn't sound sorry at all and there is not even a suggestion for any sort of help. I could accepting reschedule or rescheduled at any of your related restaurant. Anyway, you should a least trying to be sincere. Awful experience with this place.
author: Wuke Z.

description:
Seventeen seats total in the restaurant, and they only do nigiri.  We sat at the six counter sushi bar. It was fun to watch the three chefs behind the counter working their magic. The chefs were nice and talked about the fish. 

Omakase is market price but our bill came out to $220 for two plus tip, including green tea and a Hitachino hefeweisen beer, and two king salmon (the chefs said they only get this fish for one month from Alaska) nigiris for $9 each and two satsuma A5 grade beef nigiris for $15 each. So omakase by itself was probably about $80pp. Not bad!

We didn't like the food at Ijji as much as Saru, their sister restaurant, but we really liked the atmosphere and the hospitality at Ijji.  Service was superb; they refilled my tea often and were very welcoming. The chef and our server both asked us how everything was.  The chef also asked us to recall our favorite courses, so be sure to take notes while you eat!

One bonus thing that I can rarely say is how impressed I was with the bathroom here, so much so that I want to model my bathroom after it.  It was so clean, decorated beautifully, and smelled wonderful (almost certainly a pine scented Shoyeido incense from Japan).

Courses included the following:
Japanese clams and lotus roots in sesame sauce - appetizer
fatty tuna
wild horse mackerel
amberjack
arctic char
wild barracuda 
wild sea bass
live scallop

Add-ons:
copper river king salmon from Alaska (not that special of a salmon, to us)
Satsuma beef, A5 grade - seared lightly with a blowtorch - melted in our mouths

The omakase did not conclude with a tamago "dessert" so if you like your egg custard to finish off your meal, you have to order it.
author: Christina G.

description: After months of trying various different sushi restaurants in SF, Ijji is my favorite to date! It's most reminiscent of our visit to Japan. Each nigiri is perfectly sliced, seasoned, prepared and served. The detail seasoning to the rice and ratio to fish is perfect. It's simplicity of preparation highlights the flavor of each fish. Each sushi is dressed differently and paired to enhance the fish. We commented on how the soy sauce was amazing, full of flavor and not too salty. The chef nonchalantly mentioned that it was made in house. The fish that were cured and aged were also done in house. We offered the sushi chef a glass of wine that we brought with us and he offered us an extra course of clam that was off menu and tasted like abalone. It was a perfect dish. I told him that it was so amazing, he should add it to the omakase. There are much more expensive omakase places that we've compared this to and found this is the best. At $145 per person and $25 corkage, it's a clear winner for me as my new go to Japanese omakase.
author: Stephanie K.

description: One of the best omakasa dining place in the city. Superbly customer service and very elegant Japanese restaurant. Every pieces of the fishes were mouthwateringly delicious. Especially when you paired it with their recommended sake selections.
author: Jaymee C.

description: Fresh sushi and an entertaining and interesting experience! We reserved dinner for two on OpenTable and showed up to our reservation that included only one other couple (restaurant seats roughly twenty and possible seating times are predetermined). Dinner consisted of 20 courses, from sashimi, to sushi, to soups and desserts. We really enjoyed the salmon and tuna dishes. Yes- it's a bit pricey, but it was worth it. We sat at the bar and we're able to watch the chefs make each piece, describing where the fish is from, the process of making/plating it, and answering any questions you may have regarding sushi, San Francisco, or traveling in general. The conversation was pleasant and the food was delicious. Definitely recommend this spot!
author: Nick C.

description:
Well San Francisco, we have a new winner! Ijji is without a doubt, and officially the best sushi in town. Where do I even start? 

A 17 seat establishment located in DivCo, Ijji is the closest thing I've experienced to traditional Japanese omakase since my travels in Japan. Last night (3/2/16) was one of the best meals of my life. Thank you Ijji. 

Here is the order of courses: 

1. KURO MAGURO
2. KASUGODAI
3. SHIMA AJI
4. KOHADA
5. SUZUKI
6. TAI KOBUJIME
7. HOTARU IKA
8. UNI
9. ZUWAI KANI
10. KAMASU
11. SAYORI

The top three (in order) for me were the Kohada (gizzard shad, Japan), Kasugodai (wild young snapper, Japan), and Suzuki (wild sea bass, Japan). The attention to detail in preparation, fish selection and rice to fish ratio were perfection. 

This is something you need to experience first hand so I'll stop short here. It's been open for less than a month and my guess is, I'll have a hard time getting back into this place anytime soon.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
This place has been on my radar for a while and I finally got the chance to try it with my boyfriend! Parking is definitely hard to find so come early to look for parking or lyft it! 

My boyfriend and I originally thought we wanted omakase but we decided to just go with nigiri since we were able to choose what we want to try. We dined at 9pm which wasn't bad it's just that diners before us snatched up the last pieces of some of the fishes we wanted to try.

A few of our favorites were the wagyu, Hokkaido uni, cherry salmon, anago, chu toro, o-toro, and crab with crab butter. All of these were absolutely delicious and incredibly fresh! We loved every bite and wished we could have more!

The ones we weren't too fond of were the grunt line fish and Arctic char but other than that the fishes we had were delicious! 

We will definitely be back in the future! Come if you want to try some unique fishes!

Total for 2:$300
author: Stella J.

description:
3.5 STARS

I once dated a guy who poured half a soy sauce bottle into a saucer and tried to cover every crevice of his nigiri in soy sauce. He would then fumble with his chopsticks and end up dropping the nigiri on the table before he could take a bite. He would use his unwashed bare hands to pick it back up, dunk it (what was left intact) into the saucer of soy sauce again, and plop it into his mouth.  

I would look up to see the sushi chef giving us the *DEATH STARE*.

When he went to use the restroom, I jokingly whispered to the sushi chef: "Tinder...". 

The sushi chef gave the "ahhhh haaaaa" look, chuckled, and had the server bring a bottle of sake on the house. 

"Wow, how did you manage to get us free sake?", my date asked.

"For being a slob", I thought. Instead, I smiled and said, "Kanpai!" as I toasted our sake glasses.

If you're like my date, may I suggest Ijji Sushi? 

Opening on February 2nd from the owners of Saru, Ijji is a traditional sushi restaurant that serves nigiri only (no rolls) and a handful of appetizer dishes (e.g. ankimo, chawanamushi, asari soup). They don't provide soy sauce or wasabi (each nigiri is brushed with sauce and garnished with accoutrements) so don't have to worry getting death stares from the sushi chef. They provide you with an o-shibori (hot towel) to wash your hands so you can freely eat the nigiri with your hands. I always eat nigiri with my hands now because admittedly, I'm a phuckin' slob as well. Sometimes my hair and boobies ate more than I did. 

Reservations are highly recommended as it's a very small place. There's 3-4 tables for walk-ins and the sushi bar which seats 7 is reservations only. 

My friend and I made reservations for the sushi bar and opted for the omakase. There's an 8 piece minimum order and each nigiri is charged at market price ($5-$9 per a piece). 

O M A K A S E
*Appetizer - Baby octopus & baby octopus egg, and trumpet mushrooms w/ sesame sauce: http://bit.ly/1QQF1JH
*Hotate (scallop) Nigiri ($6): http://bit.ly/1Q5c2oK
*Kanpachi (amberjack) Nigiri ($6): http://bit.ly/20jUFA2
*Sawara (Spanish mackerel) Nigiri ($5): http://bit.ly/1PKkkjE
*Tai Kobujime (kelp marinated sea bream) Nigiri ($6): http://bit.ly/1ol8MJz
*Kamasu (barracuda) Nigiri ($6): http://bit.ly/1NZU3Ze
*Katsuo (wild bonito) Nigiri ($7): http://bit.ly/1RipBQx
*Tsuri Aji (wild horse mackerel) Nigiri ($5): http://bit.ly/1SZXDZR
*Kohada (wild gizzard shad) Nigiri ($6): http://bit.ly/1Q3tGD3
*Tamago Atsuyaki (Japanese sweet omelet w/ blue shrimp): http://bit.ly/1RisNMb

Everything was really fresh and the shari was properly prepared - held its form and was nicely seasoned with vinegar and sugar. The omakase as a whole was good for the price (w/ 1 beer, add-ons, tax, and 20% tip it was $100 pp) but I wasn't wow'd like Wako, Kusakabe, Akiko, and Yoshizumi. The highlights were the bonito, and tsuri aji, and the sponge cake-like tamago. I prefer the fattier fishes that melt-in-your-mouth like butter and the selection given were all firmer, lean fishes so we ordered more items a la carte. 

A  L A  C A R T E
*Ankimo (monkfish liver) Pate (Appetizer $9): http://bit.ly/23STeNA
*Umi Masu (ocean trout) Nigiri ($5): http://bit.ly/20jVQzi
*Zuwai Kani (wild snow crab w/ crab butter) Nigiri ($6): http://bit.ly/1T8HsL5
*Chutoro (medium fatty tuna) Nigiri ($6): http://bit.ly/1Ph4ICK
*Otoro (fatty tuna) Nigiri ($7): http://bit.ly/1W73fki

The ankimo was different than any other ankimos I had, it had the texture of Vietnamese cha lua (steamed pork roll). The umi masu and otoro hit the spot with its buttery texture. The chutoro was surprisingly better than the otoro, and was the best nigiri I had that night. My friend had the zuwai kani and really enjoyed it. 

The owner/sushi chef was kind enough to give us an order of the Housemade Matcha Ice Cream w/ azuki beans on the house: http://bit.ly/1PKmTCj. Good creamy texture and matcha flavor. I loved the soft creaminess of the azuki beans. 

Service was fantastic. The staff was really welcoming, cordial, and attentive. Our water glasses never went unfilled and plates were promptly cleared. 

The ambiance is very minimalist and the focal point is the sushi bar. I highly suggest sitting at the bar so you can interact with the sushi chefs and watch them in action. 

Street parking wasn't as difficult as trying to find parking several blocks down near NOPA.   

If you want to impress your date and look like you know your sushi, then Ijji is the place. If you're a chopstick fumbler like me, remember: eat the nigiri with your hands. Please just don't overdo it and start feeding your date in public, unless you want *DEATH STARES* from the rest of us.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
4.5 stars

Came here for a Thursday night dinner. I was really lucky to be able to get a sushi bar reservation just earlier that afternoon! The entire ambience is very zen and minimalistic, even the entrance is just a large unmarked wooden door. Ijji only seats about 20 people though, so be sure to get a reservation or check ahead of time.

I didn't feel the sushi bar was as worth it here (vs. a table). Service is definitely a bit faster since the chefs just hand you the sushi directly, so that's still a plus. But the chefs don't seem to talk to the customers very much, so, if that's what you're looking for....

The omakase is less structured than at other sushi places in SF. Rather than listing out the courses that you'll receive (i.e. 2 warm apps, 5 nigiri, and dessert), "omakase" is just a single option on the menu, and the chefs decide on the spot which nigiri to give you. 

We actually decided to order a la carte this time. We started with the ankimo and clam miso soup, then moved on to 7 pieces of nigiri each. The ankimo was rich and smooth and came with some seaweed and light soy sauce. I'm not usually a soup person, but the clam miso soup was really delicious. It was served with a few plump, juicy clams on the shell, and the soup itself was a beautiful blend of miso with a bit of seafood-ness.

On to the nigiri! All of the fish was really fresh, definitely high quality. The sea bream and o-toro (fatty tuna) were two that stood out to me. The chef served the sea bream with a small dot of black sesame on top. The flavor was really interesting; I had never had sesame on my nigiri before. And the o-toro, SO AMAZING!! It was slightly torched, with a brushstroke of soy sauce on top, and just melts in your mouth. We could not resist each ordering a second piece. The uni, however, was a bit disappointing. It wasn't super creamy / sweet and consisted of a few small pieces, rather than one smooth piece, over the over-abundant blob of rice.

High quality fish. Clean and simple decor. Overall delicious, but not mind-blowing. I wouldn't object to coming back again though.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Date & Time:  Sunday February 7, 2016 @ 6pm
Dining Companions:  Mommy & Husband
Scene:  Nopa Guys in Logo Start-Up Tees & Girls in Off-the-Shoulder Tops, Leather Shorts & Over-the-Knee Boots
Music:  Folk
Decor:  Rustic, Understated, Zen.  No Signage.  Intimate Dining Room that Seats 17 w/ Cypress Wood Sushi Bar which Seats 7 + 4 Tables for Parties of 2 and 4.  Reservations for Bar Seating Only
Service:  On Point  
Imbibe:  Asahi & Sake
Devour:  Omakase & Sashimi Omakase.  Apps:  Chawanmushi, Akadashi, Kani Sunomono, Ankimo.  Nigiri & Sashimi:  Akami, Chu Toro, Umi Masu, Kanpachi, Kamasu, Tai Kobujime, Hirame Korea, Akayagara, Sawara Japan, Tsuri Aji, Muki Hotate.  For Dessert:  Azuki Beans + Matcha Ice Cream
Total:  $177.91
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
This is hands down the best dinner I have had in SF and the best sushi I have had to date. (Going to Japan this fall so that may change).

UPDATE! Went to Japan... this is 100% on par with the quality of sushi we had there.

I have nothing bad to say about this place other than the  price is high. This is definitely not a casual Friday's date night, you can easily spend $300 per person here if you want food and drink. It is sooo worth it though!!! 

Like any high end sushi place, they noticed that I was left handed and served accordingly. The bites were portioned accordingly. It was a two hour experience that flew by because not only was the service perfectly timed but the environment with the relaxing music was perfect for great conversation.
author: Rachel P.

description: Satisfying 19 course menu :) Cute and cozy restaurant.. 2nd favorite behind Sasaki!
author: Kim I.

description: Been here twice. Never disappointed. The service was excellent and very quick. The menu is self explanatory but the chefs at the bar are very friendly and helpful; they'll explain why each piece after you're served.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Ijji Sushi opened in spring of 2016, with at first a variety of options in menu choices and style, in a very small space, with an almost unmarked entry, in the NoPa area on Divisadero.

But in November 2016, they switched to a Chef's Choice Prix Fixe Omakase menu only, with 2 seatings at 5:30 and 8:30. This has allowed for better food costs, better food execution, and more attention to detail. It follows along the same tasting menu Omakase style of other new (last 2 years), popular, and some Michelin Starred Sushi-ya like Wako (1*), Kusakabe (was 1*), Omakase (1*), Maruya (was *1), Ju-Ni (1*) and Sushi Yoshitomi (1*), all of which I have had the pleasure to dine in those 2 years. Hashiri (1*) was recently added to the Michelin list, but I haven't been there yet (it costs twice as much as the rest). 

The entry has no sign, only a small Ijji printed on the hanging blue entry cloths. There are only 15 seats: 7 at the sushi bar, 8 seats behind that in 3 tables. There are 3 sushi chefs. We had the privilege of sitting in the middle of the sushi bar. We  were served by Billy, the master chef, with Michelin starred training in Hong Kong. He knows his stuff, uses an unusually impressive knife set that almost looks like a Samurai short sword for Harakiri, and tastes and personally approves dashi and other accoutrements, and does the main slicing for the Nigiri part of the dinner. 

I went on 11/20/16, with my international dining companion, who has a knack for picking out Michelin Starred restaurants before they become one (i.e. Wako, Kusakabe, Omakase, Aster), which is a great money saving and rezzie getting talent! The Omakase menu that evening was in the Edomae style, and included 5 appetizers, 13 Nigiri sushi, and 2 finishing dishes. (see pictures, sorry for the blur, need to upgrade my phone?) I have a picture of the entire menu, and labelled all the pics. 

The per person price was $135, and well worth it. Chef Billy (who is Chinese) personally prepared the sushi for the 2 of us, announced each, as did his other chefs on either side of him, both Japanese, 1 originally from Kyoto, the other from Tokyo. We ordered a wonderful Junmai Dai Ginjo Sake from Akita-ken, called Chokaisan (after Chokai Yama, volcano mountain on Honshu), a Gold Medal award winning sake with a fragrant floral nose and a great smooth taste that improved through the meal ($99).  

I really like the intimate feel this place has, with a nicely paced meal of 20 courses, and the professional staff with a great appreciated and understanding of Sushi. And sitting at the bar offers the classic Sushi Chef-Diner intimacy that really makes it feel like Japan. I suspect that with their Omakase only approach they are now employing, and the high quality if maintained, may earn them a Michelin Star next October. But let me ask my international dining companion!

Go now before that happens, before the prices go up and the rezzies go down.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Hot damn! I've become a pretty big sucker for omakase in the Bay, and not just because that rhymes. Bomb quality fish you can't find anywhere else except that huge price tag. This place does that, but at an affordable rate.

We were able to make the reservation for a Friday night a couple days in advance on OpenTable. Do make sure to specify if you want a table or the bar - I saw some guests disappointed when they didn't get what they wanted.

I find it hilarious that the omakase isn't a set course menu you can follow like most places. You basically get whatever the chefs feel like that day. Not knowing the price might be a little daunting, but with maybe 12 pieces and an opening app, it sat around $70 each for my group.

I really liked our opening bites. The diced octopus included an octopus egg that felt like I was eating a giant lobster egg from Chinese restaurants. And the julienned mushrooms in sesame sauce - so simple yet a great start.

It's pretty hard for one of these places to have the best of every fish - the chances of the fish market favoring one store is just so unlikely. But overall everything meets the bar you'd expect from these places. My party universally loved the Satsuma beef, and I think the uni beat all three options I received from Kusakabe. After that is where opinions began to differ.

I will say this is one of the times I've noticed the nigiri not being universally prepped. A lot of the places I've been to have a great rice, soy sauce, and wasabi, but other than the fish on top they were all the same. Ijji actually changed how they used all these ingredients depending on the fish, which I really appreciated and kept the experience fresh.

You can never go wrong with more great sushi, and the Divisadero just got another strong contender. If you're looking to highlight your dining experience later in the week, I strongly recommend Ijji Sushi.
author: Dave N.

description:
This is a really solid option for omakase in the city. I came here a few months ago for dinner with 2 friends. We sat at the sushi counter and enjoyed beer and hot tea with our omakase meal ($135/person). No complaints about the quality of the fish -- everything was super fresh and flavorful. From what I've tried so far, I would rank omakase in the city as follows: Kusakabe, Ijji, Omakase. I can't wait to try more omakase menus!

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description: After I went it and showed the host at the restaurant my phone in person and he saw their cancellation policy was unclear in OpenTable, they refunded my money. Even though I'd sent screenshots of it via email, they didn't budge till they wasted more of my time and energy. And their owner Ryan, who was relentless and insisted repeatedly on keeping my money via email, never apologized. I'll never go back. Awful experience in customer service.
author: F S.

description:
Service: the service was outstanding. The servers were very professional and attentive. They will change out my cup of tea when it's low. Kept my plate and dining area very clean. 

Food: I've experienced a handful of omakase dinner before and Ijji just didn't stand out to me. The rice had too much vinegar flavor which was overpowering. The fish slices were thin. I've never seen a chef "cut" fish like the way our chef did, as if it looked amateur. It was $135 for omakase, which is on the average to higher price point. They had a nice selection of fish, but again, the vinegar in the rice was overpowering and it took away from the flavor of the fish. 

The overall experience was okay only. There was a lack of connection with the chefs. The main chef was more quiet as we try to make conversations with him. His assistants looked confused when it came to pushing out the next dish. I really wanted to like Ijji but unfortunately it wasn't my cup of tea especially paying close to $400 for 2 people.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
Note: The rating is purely based on food and not service or decor. If I have rate those 3 categories, it would be Food -3 stars, Decor / Service - 4 stars.

When I see a sushi chef who is struggling a bit in figuring out how to slice a fish, it's not a good sign.

In short, the quality of fish they get is definitely up-there but the quality /skill of the chef is not up to par for the price they charged. They might be able to get away with sushi newbies. This might be the reason for the 4+ stars rating.
author: Oyster K.

description:
Ijji Sushi is unique in that it's a small, traditional, high quality sushi restaurant, of which, there are only a handful in SF.  If you're thinking of dining at Ijji, first prepare yourself for the cost (the reason I deducted one star).....think of what you are used to spending at a 'typical' sushi restaurant, now double that.  What you get in return:  high quality ingredients, great sushi, attentive service, and a beautiful, minimalist setting.  

Note that Ijji is very small (approx. 4 tables for 2-4 people and seven bar seats), so you'll need to arrive early/late or make a reservation on busy nights.  I was told that the sushi bar was originally for walk-in's only, though many people make reservations specifically for the bar - and why not, it's gorgeous.  

We chose to order nigiri sushi individually so that we could make a selection of typical favorites ourselves.  The highlight was the Sakura Masu (Cherry Salmon) and the Anago Shirani (saltwater eel) - both amongst the best I've every had.  The Zuwai Kani (wild snow crab with crab butter) was the only low-light and this was because it was almost too savory and rich for one 'bite' (and was only compounded by starting with the crab appetizer.)  Regardless of the fish, the rice is how I typically judge sushi restaurants, and the rice at Ijji will blow your socks off - warm, slightly sweet, and fluffy, you keep thinking it's going to fall apart before it gets to your mouth, but it never does.

Overall, besides the price, it's truly hard to fault Ijji - and when you think about it, a dinner here is much cheaper than traveling to Japan for what may be a similar experience.  In short, to paraphrase one of my favorite movies, "If you have the means, I highly recommend making a reservation."
author: Tom G.

description: I dined here in winter of 2017 and it was, and is, the best sushi experience I've ever had. While Uchi is a close second, nothing yet comes close to Ijji Sushi. I highly recommend this place! Price may be a barrier to entry for some, but if you can save for the experience then definitely do so. Great ingredients, flavors, and presentation.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Juan D.

description:
OK so the service was impeccable.  It's not my cup of tea to have such ridged reservations but its OK.  

The service timing was fantastic they had us all done by 8pm for the next round of customers, all of whom arrived late.  The course was well engineered building from one course to the other with very deliberate steps to ensure each piece was enjoyed.  

So why 3 stars?

The sushi was good.  The chef was very imaginative without being gregarious. The presentation was impeccable.

However there were a few things that got to me for the price they are asking which for 4 people with drinks was well over $800.

- The size of the fish to the rice ratio.   very small piece of fish barely covering the rather large piece of rice.   I've lived in Japan for years this is not exactly traditional. The word "ChiChai" comes to mind.

- The fish that did arrive wasn't mind blowing.  Many of the fish came flavored with a sauce, made me wonder why?  Are they hiding something?  Those that were not flavored were small and left my palate feeling underwhelmed

- The last course was so strong it was almost overwhelming....it felt very unbalanced which stood out more against what was a very balanced, nuanced omakase.

Considering all the other very good less expensive sushi places that offer omakase or only do omakase (i.e. Wako) I struggle to recommend this place that 

1.) Isn't trying to impress anyone
2.) wants great sushi but at a price that is representative of the experience.

Do i like Wako over this place?  yes.  Especially since the course is significantly less expensive and they have a Michelin Star.  Maybe they'll get one this year.
author: Spanky M.

description: A truly excellent experience. Intimate  space. Delicious set menu.  Edo style sushi that felt special for the area.  The sushi chef was very thoughtful about the preparation of the menu and conscientious of his guests. It was definitely pricey but felt like a special experience.  Worth a visit for a special occasion.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Most inspiring omakase journey I've ever been on. 

The intention in every bite served was paramount. The quality of fish and other ingredients, the simplicity, the artistry, the pacing, and the commitment to delivering happiness are leaps and bounds ahead of any sushi dining I've ever partaken in. Not to mention, chef becomes your luminary to guide you through each bite, and is so inviting that you feel right at home. Absolutely priceless experience. 1000% going back.
author: Natalie T.

description:
Wow! This is the place to get your omakase sushi cherry popped! My friend wanted "fancy sushi' for his birthday dinner so off to Yelp I went in search of the best.  I naturally came upon this place as it is one of the higher rated omakase places in SF that didn't require you to book months in advance (I booked about a week/few days in advance and there was still plenty of seats left).  It was a prix fixed menu for $135 per person and they called me the day before to ask about any food allergies we might have (now that's when you know you're in for a great meal!).  The location was pretty random, about a 30 minute walk from 16th Mission Bart or like a $5 Uber and definitely bus-able.  When we arrived, we were seated at one of the three tables and offered the drink menu.  The host was very gracious and attentive to our needs.  The ambience was very nice, not super well-lit, but also lit enough to offer a romantic setting.  Me and the bf knew nothing about sake but knew we should try it so we ordered a bottle that sounded fruity and was recommended by the host.  It tasted like alcoholic bananas and it was delicious! When the time came for the dinner to start, we were moved to the sushi bar where we had our own nigiri chef! There were only 5 other people in the restaurant for this sitting so every pair basically had their own chef (3 in total).  

Now for the food:
The appetizers were delicious.  My favorite being the octopus since it had just the right amount of flavor.  I was hesitant to try the abalone with liver sauce because it sounded gross but it was actually pretty good! I think my least favorite appetizer was the silky seaweed with vinegar.  It was to cleanse our palette before we got into the nigiri but it was way too vinegar-y for our taste.  

Then it was off to nigiri land!
We tried a total of 15 different types of fish (14 for the omakase + 1 additional).  The traditional way of eating nigiri is to eat it with your hands so they provided us with finger sponges that had soap in them so we could wash our fingers after every nigiri! We watched as each nigiri was hand made with precision and TLC.  One by one, we were filled up with deliciousness.  By the 5th one, I actually started getting full, but I kept going because I couldn't stop my mouth from watering at all the fish.  My favorite nigiri was the O-toro, premium blue-fin tuna.  The skin was slightly crispy and it had the best fish flavor my mouth has ever tasted.  I definitely had a foodgasm.  As each nigiri was being made, the chef would explain what it was and a little about each fish.  My least favorite was the sea urchin since the texture of it was not what I was used to for sushi.  The seaweed that they used was the perfect crisp, none of that soggy crap you get at other sushi restaurants.  The most interesting one I thought was the tamago atsuyaki since they put blue shrimp in it, it wasn't your typical tamago nigiri.  The chef explained how usually it takes 30 minutes to make normal tamago but for this one, it took them 4 hours to get the perfect mixture. 

To finish off the meal, we got red miso soup with manila clams in it.  Pretty good to me.  And for dessert, we got green tea ice cream with red bean on top.  Standard.

Overall, the experience was definitely amazing.  The service was over the top and the fish was super authentic and fresh.  I would highly recommend to all my friends looking to pop their omakase cherry!

PS if you go to the bathroom, you will come back to your napkin neatly folded on the table.  It is amazing.  Also, the bathrooms are super clean!
author: Cynthia L.

description: Splendid. Walked in! Accepted price as challenge. Met, exceeded on every count -- perfect fish well presented and sequenced, quiet service, and so small as to support the privilege of eating refined  food in a special place with special friends.
author: Peter N.

description: Phenomenal. Aging of fish, perfectly curated progression through deep flavors (balanced with fat), gorgeous clean flavors in the appetizers to start you off, and a lovely experience at the bar with the chefs. Majority of the 23 courses were heaven. Totally blown away by the uni dish which was served as a combo of the Hokkaido & Santa Barbara. Have never seen that in all my travels and treks through high-end sushi restaurants. But my favorites were the  8-day ages lean bluefin, barracuda, and that most of the fish were wild and were specified when line-caught. BEAUTIFUL.
author: Marina N.

description:
Same owners as Saru.. Hi Billy and Alex! We came here for my friend's birthday and sat at the sushi bar. We had piece after piece and ate our way through the nigiri menu. There was an extensive list of variety of fish and the staff were all extremely nice and friendly. 

The fish were all delicious and you can tell everything was high quality. I loved the simplicity of the decor inside. It's not a big place, it's not trying to mass produce and move people in and out. I loved the sushi and this is probably one of my favorite places in SF now. WAY BETTER than Ju-ni for the same price. Great for a special occasion! I hope I come back someday soon :D
author: Joanna S.

description:
~$120-140 Omakese well worth it! Sushi was fresh and of great quality. Service we top notch as well. My friend and I booked reservations online and came early to avoid the crowds. Both of us have tried out most of the higher end sushi restaurants in the area and found this place to be a solid choice. Toro, wagyu, Uni, etc were all excellent -- as expected from a place like this. This place is inline with traditional sushi and omakese was inline with that idea.

At the time, I didn't realize this place had the same owner as Saru, and comparing the two, I enjoyed this place much more. I live in soma and this place took a little longer to get to, but it was worth the drive!
author: James S.

description:
Same people behind Saru, a restaurant I heard good things about but still haven't been to due to it's usual long waits. Ijji is a fancier version and though the restaurant is small, you can make reservations in advance (easily on Opentable too). 

Friday night dinner at 7:30pm. Checked in with the host and got seated immediately. Since reservations were made same day, there were no counter seats available even though I made that note when I made the reservation. 

We were introduced to the menu by the waiter who said their omakase offers at least ten pieces of nigiri with a couple 'starters' and he recommends to order a few more starters 'they are kind of like tapas' he said. 

FOOD is very well prepared with most dishes either marinated or aged. 
ASARI akadashi- red miso based soup with clams. Very earthy! Clams are fairly large, larger than I expected
SWEET fish- their special item of the day, 5 tiny sweet fishes aged for 2 days, served with kelp. Very tasty and tastes like Chinese sweet preserved fish. 
ANKIMO NITSUKE- one of my absolute favorite items of the night, and I DO NOT even like ankimo! I never order it, but husband likes it, so I'll eat it when he orders it. So glad he ordered it bc it's the best ankimo I've ever had. I'd eat ankimo is it tastes like this ever time!
MARINATED mushrooms- one of the starters that comes with the omakase. Marinated with sesame flavored dressing, good texture
SQUID with its own eggs- the other starter. Also great texture and a nice contrast to the sweet tasting mushrooms
NIGIRI (10 pcs)- Kanpachi (amberjack, Japan), Hirame (halibut, Korea), Skipjack, Tai Kobujime (kelp marinated wild sea bream (Japan), Isaki (wild three line grunt, Japan), Kohada (wild gizzard Chad, Japan), Tsuri aji (wild horse mackerel, Japan), Sakura sake (cherry salmon, Japan), Hotate ika (wild firefly squid, Japan), Kasugodai (wild Young snapper, Japan), Wagyu (Japanese A5 beef, Japan). MY absolute favorite of this bunch was the cherry salmon, it's delicate and light in flavor with a hint of fragrant sakura, I really wanted to eat my husband's piece too but that would be too shellfish of me. It was a lot better than the cherry salmon we had at another Jpn restaurant a week ago. Waiter said cherry salmon is only in season for 2 months in the year... I'm guessing around cherry blossom season? The firefly squid and wagyu was also amazzzing. 
UNI- ordered 2 pc nigiri after omakase. Pretty good for Japanese uni found here. I was not wow'ed (since I've had better Japanese uni), but I was told by another Japanese cuisine chef that this year has not been a great year for Japanese uni so this year's uni just doesn't taste as good. Nevertheless, it was carefully and well prepared, rice was on point.
Tamago Atsuyaki- ordered 2 pc as our dessert! Made with organic egg custard and blue shrimp. Sooooo good. I could taste the tiny hint of seafood from the shrimp! Texture was almost like a honey cake, but more refined
SWEET POTATO BEER- good beer, served in a fancy ceramic(?) pint
ENDLESS hot tea- I must have had at least 6 cups during our meal

SERVICE/STAFF were helpful and courteous. You could see there were at least 6 chefs behind the counter working, a couple servers, one waiter, and one hostess. Each item was clearly introduced when brought to us and staff asked us how we were doing from time to time. Tea cup was never empty (I like!)

AMBIANCE/DECOR is simple and elegant. Noise level is average, not super quiet due to the fact that it's a small space with three tables and several counter seats, but intimidate enough for a lovely date. 

Overall, a lovely restaurant for some traditional nigiri/omakase and small dishes that are all prepared really well. I overheard the table next to us talk about Ijji compared to Kusakabe- the gentlemen said he likes Kusakabe more. I personally feel like it's hard to choose one over the other because it is comparing two different styles. Ijji is about taking Japanese seafood and preparing it in an excellent way, it is more traditional Japanese whereas Kusakube involves some less traditional techniques and concepts.  I like them both. I like Japanese food, as long as it's solid :P
author: Iris H.

description:
there was a time when i would try to be at every single opening of every single restaurant in sf. no joke. 

hell, there was a time when i helped start this yelp thing, helped build the first yelp community in sf, organized their bay to breakers team.... 

but alas, time passes one, people get old and companies get huge. 

not sure why it took me this long to try ijji. of course i read about their opening, heard mixed things from friends that have tried it, but last night, the wife and i got to try it out finally. good timing, it was our one year wedding anniversary. 

right to it. 

if you havent been and are looking for an outstanding representation of a traditional edo era omakase, this is place should be in your rotation. if you think pabu is a good edo era omakase, dont come here. if you get that pabu is a michael mine interpetation of a traditional dining experience he is "disneylanding" for mass consumption while this "new" trend is hot, then you will like this place. 

we got lucky and got seated right in front of the boss man. the boss man is direct, kind and knowledgeable. he knows what hes doing. 

this place reminding us of many of the meals we had in japan over the years. highly focused, very detail oriented, simple yet elegant meals. 

absolutely in the rotation.
author: Euge L.

description:
Visited for the first time for an anniversary dinner. Found out that this place was open on 2/14/2017 and just began serving "omakase" since 11/2016.

I didn't take any photo because I wanted to enjoy the whole meal and experience. First 4 dishes are appetizers. Then the sushi roller coaster. If you don't like what's listed from the omakase sushi menu, you can tell them to switch to something else. Don't hesitate- just ask if they are able to. At the end of the meal they serve soup and desert.

It took 2 hour + from start to finish. Over all, any "omakase" place you visit in SF are for those who don't travel to Japan often to enjoy the edomae sushi. But because I'm from Japan, and been to Tsukiji multiple time to experience fresh market fish (medium toro etc) for a fraction of the cost, it was to experience the hype of it (basically I'm spoiled).

Would I recommend this place? - yes, you should come visit place at least once. 
Would I come back again? - sure but only for special occasion.
author: Aya M.

description:
Nothing special about this sushi restaurant. The sushi rice was still warm when they served the nigiri. The ingredients are fine but the chef wasn't creative enough to present a meal that wow'd the patrons. 

For $400, I'd prefer another omakase restaurant in the city.
author: Moko R.

description:
Having been to majority bay area's top sushi restaurant.

I would rank this place #4- Behind Sushi Yoshizumi, Kusakabe, and distant 3rd Wako.

Let me start with the positive.

Environment and service

1.  Our Chef Alex (Korean) was extremely detailed and always keep his counter clean.  There are no cross over taste on any of his dishes.  I am very impressed by our sushi chef. 

2.  The caucasian waiter was extremely knowledgeable and provide services you would only expected from Japanese servers.  He was probably one of the better waiter that I have met in Sushi place in US.

Sushi-

Pro-

1.  The treatment of fish was excellent.  The flavoring was very creative.  I was really impressed by this-  I will go into detail below.

A. Nama Tako-  use of sakura powder and salt really brings out the flavor of Tako.  Well done.
B.  Aji- one of my favorite fish- the fish was sweet and comes with just right amount of ginger and onion.  (This would have been exceptional- but the rice really really underwhelmed)
C.  Belt fish- the fish was perfectly seared with salt and ginger on top. 
D.  Firefly squid- this was the best dish of the night.  As the nori combined with the rice and perfectly marinated squid.  Excellent dish.
E.  Anago-  Not as good as Kusakabe- but still one of the better in the bay area.

Issues-

1.  Rice-  the rice was way too sticky and undercooked at same time.  Its also extremely blend.  Every single Nigiri (other than firefly squid)- the fish over powered the rice.  Its just extremely blend rice and cater to american taste buds.  

2.  Cherry Salmon- the marinate wasn't good enough.  Complete lack of flavor.  Sushi Yoshizumi cherry salmon (which I had on wed) completely destroyed Ijji.  I really felt sorry for the poor trout.

3.  Negi-Toro-  This is also just awful.  The Toro was quiet fatty.  But the scallion and the ginger wasn't mixed well.  All i taste is just fat.  One of the worse ever.  

4.  Tamako Atsuyaki-  please do not make Tamako Atsuyaki if you can't make it right.  it was just pure sugar and dry.  Like Omakase- both of their Tamako are simply not up to par.

Overall-  this is more like a 3.5 (since yelp does not allow .5 star).  Its better than Omakase (which i am not sure how it got michelin one star).  Its just below Wako.  

I really enjoyed dinner here.  But just too many mistakes and rices is simply not up to standard really killed the rating for me.

I really hope that they could offer traditional Japanese style rice.  It really could be a lot better with just change of rice.  Also, the wasabi also needs to improve.

I can feel that they put a lot of effort into their fish.  Please improve on the rice and wasabi!!!!!
author: Jerry W.

description:
I never imagined I'd be this impressed with a sushi bar in San Francisco. Everything is as close to perfection as can be. I'll definitely be back in autumn again when the menu changes :)
まさかサンフランシスコのお寿司屋さんで感動したとは思ってもいませんでしたね。全てにおいて限りなく完璧に近かったです。季節ごとに品書が変わるらしいのでまた秋にお邪魔します(´｀)
author: Roger F.

description: This is by far the most honest omakase place I have been to in SF. It reminds me of Japan where they let the quality of ingredients speak for itself, and not rely on exotic ingredients and fancy presentation for the wow factor. Everything is executed with precision: the sushi rice is seasoned perfectly, each piece of fish is cut to the right size and thickness, the ratio of fish to rice is just right for a single bite. I remarked to the sushi chef about how beautiful the soy sauce is - full of flavor without being too salty (I think I even used the word sublime). And he nonchalantly remarked that he made it himself, like it is no big deal. So... a little bit of a back story about me here, my mom happened to be obsessed with good soy sauce and once sent me artisanal soy sauce (yes, it's a thing) home from Asia. I prayed it wouldn't explode in my luggage, and it did survive so I do know something about great soy sauce :) Anyway, I digress. My point is, these people are hardcore purists, I could taste it in the freshly ground wasabi and ginger as well. On to service: I brought a bottle of Puligny-Montrachet, La Truffière to drink with dinner, and offered a glass to the chef, which he graciously accepted and slipped in an extra course that was not even on the menu! It was a very fantastic clam dish that had the umami and toothiness of abalone. Understandably, people on both sides of me at the sushi bar shot me an envious look. The wait staff in general were quietly​ attentive without being obstrusive, almost ninja-like. This place totally transported me to Japan. I get this place, it is utterly honest and unpretentious, and there is beauty in premeditated simplicity. There is no clutter, just purity distilled to its essence... like great calligraphy. I struggled to give this place an excellent review because I know once word gets out reservations will be much harder to come by, but I can't be selfish. Well done, Ijji, don't ever change, save your genius for those who get you!
author: Puay K.

description: Easily one of the best omakase experiences we've had. Such attention to detail, from the food to the service. Everything tasted amazing, and the nigiri was so flavorful. Will definitely be back!
author: Timothy L.

description:
woohoo the best experience!

bf took me here for my birthday over the weekend and i can't stop thinking about this meal. you know that documentary "jiro dreams of sushi"? well this isn't quite as epic, but definitely dreaming of ijji and that fresh fish!

i love the intimate environment here. 7 seats at the sushi bar and 4 tables of two, that's it. definitely request a seat at the sushi bar when making your reservation - it's one of those can't-take-your-eyes-off-of-it experiences getting to watch the sushi chefs prepare each piece of nigiri with such care and precision. 

each fish is seasoned exactly the way the chef thinks it is best prepared, so you won't find any extra soy sauce or wasabi laying around in this joint. but what i can't get over is how fresh the fish is (compared to what the rest of sf generally has to offer) and how the art of cutting enhances the overall taste and melt-in-your-mouth factor of each piece of fish.

the omakase is a nice introduction to a range of fish that ijji offers. but i'd recommend ordering a la carte if you know exactly what kinds of fish you like. while the omakase is great for those who want to try a range of fish without the pressure of choosing each one, there are some "lesser favorites" in the bunch. next time i go back, i'm going straight for my favorites: otoro, chutoro, uni, wagyu, squid, hokkaido clam, and snapper.

ijji also has a fantastic selection of sakes, we really enjoyed our waiter's recommendation of the konteki daiginjo for its light taste and smooth finish. though finishing the bottle between two people did leave us with a very good buzz, having forgotten that sake has a slightly higher alcohol content than wine :)
author: Yiwen S.

description:
Sushi that's worth the price in SF? Rare find. Would definitely recommend this to any sushi fans looking for an omakase sushi experience without (completely) breaking the bank.

The omakase here is a set $135 and is the only thing you can order. This lets you not worry about what to pick and just relax and enjoy the food.

The fish was fresh and the preparation was simple yet delicious. I really like how they don't overseason their fish like a lot of other places.

While you can only get the omakase, they also offer you a much smaller menu towards the end with some items you can order separately!
author: Jess L.

description: Came here for a special occasion & absolutely loved it. Sat at the chef's counter for a superb array of crafted sushi. Loved the food, the ambiance & the attentive & kind service. Definitely worth the money for the experience!
author: Paull Y.

description:
This place offers omakase, small appetizers, and a bunch of other nigiris at very reasonable price... Bill came out to be only around $200 that that's including a half-bottle of sake. I wasn't that full, but if I REALLY wanted to be completely stuffed, i think the bill would be $300 maximum for 2 people.

As for quality of food... definitely top notch. Some pieces of fish were not as flavorful, but I'm biased... because I tend to go for the fat oily pieces only lol
author: Betty T.

description:
Honestly, I wasn't crazy about this place. 

Too much shiso stuff on sushis and they were out of fatty tuna. Uni and hotate were good but the rest was just okay. 

Wako on clement is so much better because they give you more appertizers, soup and desert too. 


Service was weird too. This white guy waiter kept pushing my chopsticks towards the middle of the table when he brought out more food. You are supposed to keep your chopsticks close to you. It was kind of annoying. This is a $$$$ sushi place, you should prob educate your waitresses and waiters on table manners. 


So for those reasons, I'm not going back to this place.
author: C M.

description: YUM!!!!  Second time doing omakase and this has been the yummiest. I enjoyed all the dishes. My server was attentive and very knowledgable. Would recommend if in the city. My only complaint was that you could only ask for specific fishes at the end and not the one I had enjoyed the most out of the tasting menu.
author: Veronica R.

description:
I am a huge fan of omakase sushi. I found out about this restaurant when I saw a list by OpenTable of the top 100 restaurants in the US. When I checked the website I had to try this. The only way to dine here is to make a reservation well in advance. There are no parking lots nearby so you have to unfortunately need to find street parking. Restaurant has no large signs so it can be easily missed. The place only seats about 16 people, with a bar and 2 small tables. The venue is very nice and the service is top notch as they are attentive and they spend time explaining what each coarse contains.

The menu changes from day to day so the courses I mention may not be available if you try. Here is the menu I had on Dec 29 2016:

5 Appetizers: 
Kaki Ohitashi (oyster), Chu-Toro (fatty bluefin tuna), Tako Yawaraka Ni (octopus), Tai Simon (sea bream with some noodle), Mozuku (silky seaweed with vinegar)

Main dishes:
Hirame Kobujime (kelp cured halibut), Kasugodai (wild young snapper), Zuke Akami (bluefin tuna), Toro (fatty bluefin tuna), Medai (wild Japanese butterfish), Tsuri Aji (wild horse mackerel), Kamasu (wild barracuda), Masaba (wild mackerel), Hotate (sea scallop), Uni (wild sea urchin), Zuwai Kani (wild snow crab), Anago (salt water eel), Tamago Atsuyaki (organic egg custard)

Dessert:
Adkadashi (red miso based soup), Ice Cream (green tea with azuki)

The top main dishes in my opinion are
1. Toro (fatty tuna). My favorite
