2. Uni (sea urchin). It is double layered uni, one from Hokkaido and one from Santa Barbara. Delicious
3. Zuke Amami (soy cured bluefin tuna)
4. Tsuri Aji (wild horse mackerel)
5. Hotate (sea scallop)
6. Anago (salt water eel)
7. Zuwai Kan (wild snow crab w/ crab butter)

This place is expensive, $135/person. It only serves only omakase so you cannot order anything like rolls or teriyaki. This is definitely a place to go for special occasions or if you have an extreme hunger for omakase.
author: Richard L.

description:
I've been to ijji a few times and it's always been good. 

Last night, I tried their new prix fixe menu and it blew my mind. 

I am not exaggerating in the least when I say that the quality of ingredients, focus on the details (obsession on the details) and variety of flavours used made this the best meal of my life. 

I've eaten omakase all over Japan, and this exceeds the best experiences I've had out there. 

It's pricy (135/person) but it's worth every penny. This was a truly incredible experience.
author: Michael G.

description:
Ijji Sushi is unique to many of the sushi joints out there.  I was invited for their soft opening and was thoroughly impressed by this quaint, tiny restaurant.  

Our party of four decided to go with the omakase which did not disappoint.  Most of the fish is from Japan which had some different types I never tried like horse mackerel.  The uni was the best I'd ever tasted minus the seaweed and quail egg usually embellishing this delicacy.  Everyone's favorite was the sweet, buttery flavors of the pink sea trout.  We enjoyed a smooth bottle of sake which complimented our sushi well.  I tried a dark lager Japanese beer which was served in a metal cup and goes well with the minimalistic, modern-rustic themed interiors.  We also enjoyed the hearty chawamushi with fish, clams and other seafood novelty ingredients.  I decided to try the eggplant (Nasu Nibitashi? if I can recall).  I enjoyed chilled eggplant for the first time unbeknownst to me.  I've not seen it this way on other menus before.  I'd indulge again too!

The most unique thing about Ijji is the absence of the sushi/sashimi essential condiments most are used to:  soy sauce, wasabi, and ginger. I appreciate that, and it shows the transparency in the grade of fish and its freshness.  I could have enjoyed it sashimi style, but draped over a slightly sweet oblong piece of sushi rice was most complimentary and the main focus here.  I did not miss the usual enhancements!

Did I mention the friendly, attentive and knowledgeable service?  They know their sake pairings and will point out the fish types served.

If you're interested in a uniquely different sushi experience,  you have to come here!  I highly recommend reservations though.  Ijji only seats about 20.  I would undoubtedly take another jaunt here next time I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Two words: delicious and fresh!

The place only seats maybe 15-20 people max. I came here with a group of 5 people. It was nice and intimate.

I had the omakase and I would come back and do this again. 

I highly recommend the Nama Tako. This is the first time I've seen this on a menu and it was delicious. My friends were raving about the uni the whole time.

The only thing I have to say is, it's quite expensive. I ended up spending $125 (including sake split among 5 people and extra pieces of sushi) and I wasn't full.

Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Ambiance: 5/5
Price: 4/5
author: Tiana C.

description:
Well my husband and I had dinner at Ijji twice in a month. The first time we gave it a try after I found a new Japanese place in town. It was amazing for that try. We ordered the omasake set. Its unbelievable tasty. 
We came back after 3 weeks. Not trying anymore. 
I can say I love all the nigiri but the most one is 'cherry salmon with a cherry leaf' called 'sakuramasu' - its the most seasonal, the chef said it comes only two months in a year. I guess its during the cherry blossom season. 
Service is good. The chef standing at the middle is very nice and friendly. 
The decor of Ijji is very classy and minimal.
author: Hanh N.

description:
I got my omakase cherry popped at this elegant and intimate joint, serving only 14 customers at a time. My boyfriend and I arrived here on a Saturday night in celebration of my birthday. We were lucky to find a parking spot moderately close by because the area was fairly packed.

Ijji only has two timeslots for dinner, 5:30 and 8:30, as the dinner takes AT LEAST 2 hours to get through. We booked the earlier slot, and were advised to arrive half an hour early. We did, and had to wait outside in the cold for 5 minutes :( but didn't bother us much. We were seated at a table for 2, and in hindsight, I really wished I chose the sushi bar! The experience would have been much more fulfilling. 

FOOD: we had a total of 20 courses, started with kusshi oysters as amuse bouche and ended with house made matcha icecream with azuki beans. The most notable dishes were the abalone with seaweed and abalone liver sauce, the slow cooked wagyu beef with daikon, the zuke chu-toro nigiri (soy cured med-fat blue fin tuna) and of course my favourite, the uni. Everything had THE perfect balance in flavor and texture, and seriously made me want to cry from joy!!

SERVICE: The servers were very attentive; our water glasses were never empty, each dish was well-explained to us when they were served, and they folded our napkins everytime we got up from our chair to go to the bathroom. I do, however, wish they smiled more!

Overall, this was just a wonderful experience, though it came at a hefty price of $135 (excl. alcohol). I would skip out of 10 mediocre meals just to have this more often!! Can't wait to come back!!
author: Ivy W.

description:
5/5. The king salmon and anago are the best I have ever had in my life. Beltfish and horse mackerel are amazing too. 
The dessert (soybean ice cream) is literally now one of my favorite desserts ever; it is rich with a nice gritty texture.
Ijji is a nigiri-only restaurant, but unlike many other high end sushi restaurants you are not required to get the omakase before a la carte.
The waiter is great and always remembers my requests. Service is amazing all around.
Nice ambience.
Price is very good for the quality you get.
I will be back soon!
author: J L.

description: OMAKASE was perfectly prepared. Off course all SUSHI NETAs are fresh and Sushi chef skills are incredible!! I really enjoyed your work and GOCHISO SAMADESHITA!!
author: Maki K.

description: Better than the first time I went last year after switched to the single omakase menu.  Might be my favorite omakase in SF, topping Wako which is an impressive feat.  The sushi chef took the time to explain each course and the seasonality of the fish, which was much appreciated.  They also have fish that I haven't seen anywhere else.  Will be back again and again.
author: Cathy B.

description: Fantastic service and extremely well paced and delicious omakase. It is a great experience.
author: Beau M.

description:
Our dinner at Ijji was quintessential and one of the best omakase we have had throughout the world, including Japan. Each small, beautiful plate had a perfect balance of flavors, temperature and texture. They are masters in bringing just the right salty, sweet, sour, bitter and umami, then hot, warm and/or cold, and lastly elements of smooth, creamy, chewy and crispy often in the same bite. The last variable was the season and we were lucky to hit the beginning of the cherry blossom blooming so that was incorporated into the Sakura Masu or cherry salmon. Each dish was like a three level chess game of complexity and beautiful tastes.

 Alex, our chef for the night, paced our mind blowing plates perfectly and spoke to us about each dish as it was presented. He highlighted the differences in tasting of the item and explained where it was sourced from and what type of influence the location had on the flavor compared to other well know source locations for the same product.  

Surprising standouts outside of the sushi/ sashimi were the Mozuku, a silky seaweed with pear in vinegar from Ishikawa that captured the perfect little ocean, and the Akadashi, red miso soup with egg tofu. The best miso soup I have ever had and the tofu was prepared like a perfect little souffle.

Our only recommendations to the restaurant would be to add a sake pairing to the menu, we created our own and the matcha Ice-cream needed one more texture element and perhaps a little something acidic to counter the creaminess richness of the ice cream as well as the smooth, subtle sweet of the azuki.

Definitely a wonderful restaurant that we highly recommend and look forward to returning.
author: Anna S.

description:
This is a nice place but not for the price and not for the delivery.  It is nice because it is small and simple; the food is nice but not special.

The ambiance the night we went was comfortable 3/4 full, which means about 9 to 10 people.  

The wait staff was solicitous.  I didn't enjoy the hovering or hand wringing feel that they conveyed.

The food was common actually.  The presentation was the bomb!  But, sadly one can't eat presentation in the same manner.

ps.  My date sucked so take my review with a grain of salt.
author: S P.

description:
This is a culinary experience that makes the taste buds very happy. My first experience with Uni was here and it was a good one!

It is extremely pricey as it only serves its $135/person Omakase menu (this price has even gone up since we ate there a few months ago), but it's definitely worth it for a special occasion! 

You can sit at the bar and watch the chefs make their edible art, or choose to sit at a small table - the restaurant is San Francisco tiny, so it's "strongly recommended" (pretty much required) that you make a reservation.
author: Stephanie C.

description: The sushi was the best I've had outside of Japan and the service and atmosphere were as good as it gets. The knowledge of the waitstaff was incredible - better by far than at Kusakabe, Wako, or any of the other Sushi restaurants I've been to in SF. This restaurant is an under the radar standout in the SF sushi scene. Check it out before the Michelin guide finds out about it!
author: Nicholas S.

description:
Nice and cozy environment to enjoy good omakase/nigiris and sake while hanging out with friends. Food was great and everyone was super friendly, including the tables next to us. :) Not a large menu, but definitely a good selection of freshness that you can taste. 
** No soy sauce needed!! **
author: Cynthia W.

description: My friend and I came here before the omakase was upgraded and expanded (I'm on a budget so I had to come here before the price went up). I'm thinking the expanded omakase and the higher price is well worth it (I might save up my money and come back again rather soon!) because the fish was so fresh, flavorful and unforgettable. Loved it! We ordered a couple pieces of the ones we wanted to savor a little more. The service was very thoughtful and explained each piece carefully and respectfully. I want to come back again soon! I need to save my money, but I know it will be worth it!
author: Maile N.

description: We went for dinner on a Saturday night for the second seating. What an incredible experience. We were sat at the bar so got to watching the chef and his team prepare each course. It was such a special meal, and delicious! Care and thought was evident in each moment, thank you so much for a wonderful evening!
author: Robyn B.

description:
I thought I knew sushi before I came here...

Ijji, a new spot on Divis exceeds all expectations.
-Delightful decor
-Excellent service

The sushi. 
I've never eaten sushi with my hands before, but let me tell you, it's awesome. Dining becomes an activity, not just a meal. Make sure to sit at the bar.

How to eat sushi at Ijji:
1. Chef expertly whips up sushi, adds any sauce, etc. that it needs. 
-You don't get the option of adding your own soy sauce and wasabi, which I usually loveeee doing. However, I was pleasantly surprised that it was not needed.
2. Chef places the single piece of sushi on your plate.
3. You pick up the sushi with your hand and place in mouth.
4. ENJOY!
5. Wipe fingers with the oshibori (small towel wipe).
6. Repeat :)

My a la carte order:
-Akami Maguro (lean tuna)
-Toro (fatty tuna)
-Katsuo (wild bonito)
-Umi Masu (ocean trout) x2 : this was one of my favorites
-Tsuri Aji (mackerel)
-Tai Kobujime (sea bream)
-Uni (sea urchin): so buttery and delicious
-A5 beef

Every piece was great. Each individual piece ranges $6-15. I ate around 9 pieces and definitely could have had more.

My advice, go here before it becomes too popular. It's a splurge but definitely worth it.
author: Rachel R.

description: Among all the Michelin guide recommended Japanese restaurant in Bay Area, I personally don't recommend this place to you. The decoration and service, to be honest, are beyond excellent, but the sushi is not outstanding enough to worth the price. However, I really like the way they do Kamasu nigiri. It's very traditional and unique. To sum up, I'd recommend couples to go try that place. It's a good experience after all.
author: Annabelle L.

description:
This was my personally experience. My wife took me here for my birthday and the sushi was very very good, super high quality. Super fresh, taste amazing. 11 pieces. All very good.
 Service was great. Super friendly. 

But when you spend $250 for the omakasa (for 2) I expect to be full and not have to go to in and out afterwards. This left me super disappointed. I know sushi isn't cheap, but being hungry after a nice meal, huge let down. 

Food- 5stars
Value- 1star
author: eric c.

description: Excellent place to splurge on perfectly prepared fish. After alcohol, extra fish and tip, it came to $500 for two of us. And it was worth it.
author: Susan J.

description:
I lived in Japan and was very excited when I walked through the entrance to Ijji. The space has all the makings of a traditional sushi restaurant in Japan. 

Unfortunately the sushi did not live up to expectations. Fish was not cut uniformly, and non-sushi dishes were very disappointing. 

My dining companion and I left starving and about $160 poorer. The tiny portions need to be of exceptionally high quality to demand such high prices.
author: William R.

description:
Was looking to try Edomae style sushi ever since I got back from Japan and experienced it at Jiro's (yes, that Jiro's).  And Ijji was the better experience!  I must admit, I don't know how authentic Ijji's Edomae is compared to Jiro's, which I assume to be the epitome of authentic, but it was just more palatable.  Maybe I wasn't used to the intense vinegar marinade of all the fish at Jiro's.  Ijji's definitely used vinegar, but it was much more subtle, as it enhanced rather than overpowered.  

I had the omakase, which varies daily in offering and price.  The star of the bar was as expected--the O-Toro.  Think of all the sushi clichés:  melt-in-mouth, fresh, etc.

And the service and attention from the wait staff to the sushi chefs were unparalleled.  Friendly, engaging and upbeat.  Another contrast to the solemn, sushi-Nazi style of Jiro's.  In the end, the omakase turned out to be 10 pieces for $84.  It was half the size of Jiro's, but one-third the price...for a better experience.  I think we have a winner...
author: Lionel C.

description: Another great place for high end sushi slurges. My favorite was their aji and barracuda. All the dishes were well made.
author: Herb L.

description:
Took my friend to try out their new omakase menu last night! It was perfect! 

$135 is well worth it.
Every course is well thought of and prepared. 
Ingredients are fresh and picked for the season.
Very cozy, family like place to relax and enjoy great food with friends!

My personal favorite would be the awabi, its silky buttery liver sauce is a pleasant surprise.
The mozuku just tells you how thoughtful they are with their menu as it cleanses and refresh your taste buds before we head onto our nigiri.
The knife work on the sanma is meticulous, almost making it too beautiful to be eaten. 
Uni, of course, is the best but I'm biased.
Before serving anago, our itamae asked if we'd love to revisit/add any other nigiri. Both my gf and I wanted to try the akamatsu! What a gem! It's a light taste fish that simply melts in your mouth! Must try!
Tamago atsuyaki is very fluffy almost like a sponge cake! 
They sear on hinobi which infuses a zesty perfume into the sashimi. Yum

Can't wait to go back again!
author: AE W.

description:
I over-heard the place is only opened since Valentine's Day this year (2016) so a new place. 

The omakase set is really good. We ended up ordering two additional pieces (tamago and O Toro) to make sure our tummy is 100% filled. 

The head chef was very tough on the other sushi chef in front of the customer. Since it's an open kitchen and we sat in front at the sushi bar, we can see everything... 

My opinion, is, you can be extremely tough to your staff but please do it behind the scene where customer can't see. It made me feel bad and a little uncomfortable. 

But overall it's authentic omakase sushi. Wouldn't mind 2nd or 3rd visit.
author: George C.

description:
i was very excited to try ijji sushi - the same owners as saru, which doesnt take reservations and is a huge deterrent for me. whoops - maybe one day because yelp photos from saru look amazing.

made a reservations online for dins with 2 of my girlfriends who adore sushi - requested seats at the bar and were seated there so we can watch all of the action - SCORE. there are like 4 chefs behind the counter, and each party is kinda assigned one chef. they also plate items for the tables. it's a very small intimate space, seats 20 people max (6-8 at the bar), so definitely make reservations! i barely looked at the menu since we were all here for omakase, which is market price - 8 piece minimum with a small app (ankimo + mushrooms with sesame sauce, which was deeelicious).  we all added 4 pieces to the set - unagi, barracuda, cherry salmon and another piece of uni (obviously).  the omakase is just priced per piece from the regular menu - we only understood this when the check came ha. also shared a bottle of junmai for $54 which i thought was pretty expensive, and that was the lowest priced one!  $140 per person after tax & tip - not a cheap evening.

there were some pieces that were stellar - uni, barracuda, baby squid (super interesting texture too), but most were just okay. i'd come back since it is one of the better places we've tried recently, but probably wont be running back..
author: Christina L.

description:
When my girlfriends asked where do you want to go for your birthday, I usually always say some good Omakase because my hubby doesn't eat seafood. (sigh)

They picked Ijji and we got the bar seating. For such a small restaurant there are a lot of workers. The service was excellent. The best service I've had for a Japanese restaurant. Our server refilled our drinks and even changed out the little wet nap for you where you wipe your fingers after eating the nigiri with your hands. From what I know, no place has ever done that yet. 

For the Omakase you get 10 items- 1 appetizer and 9 pieces of nigiri. It says MP, but when the bill came they just charge you by each piece. It wasn't a set price like $85 or $100. The price was still reasonable, but thought that was a big odd. Never seen that yet for omakase. 

We got a few apps to start off with. This seaweed broth thing which looked really weird, but it was pretty good. More like very thin seaweed noodles in a cold broth. The chawanmushi was good. Had a lot of fish and other seafood in it. The snow crab was refreshing, but nothing wow. 

Now for the fishes. So delicious. All of them had a different flavor. The rice was really good and super fresh. 2 things I never tried was live octopus and barracuda. It was very good. Also the appetizer they gave us was ankimo and sesame mushrooms-delish!

After our set, we ordered some other things to try. Got the scallop, which was a thumbs up and my friend told me to get this one fish that is suppose to have some smokey flavors. It just tasted like a plain ahi tuna to me. Also had to try the tamago-they mix it with a bunch of seafood and said it was flourless, but it was too dense for me. 

For the price, it was good, but still not the best. Sushi Ran and Sushi Yoshizumi are still my favorite.
author: Karen H.

description: You are paying a premium for a personal sushi chef. Most dishes were good but we've had much better in this style for the price. Could not get to the end, needed to cut the menu early. Booked it again for Valentine's Day as a second try but concerned we will feel like we wasted an evening again. Best thing is set seating where the door isn't constantly opening to the cold. Very small don't get there early.
author: Olivia M.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants in SF.  I wasn't completely sure if I remembered correctly that it's related to Saru, until we had our first bites of nigiri and yep, there is that fresh taste of raw fish and well-cooked rice grains.  

We had the omakase.  10 different beautiful pieces of nigiri that never got boring.  The ones with a more subtle flavor were enhanced with overnight marinate or light garnish like ginger and scallion.  Each mouthful was complex and interesting and never settled for one note. 

After the 10 pieces, we each had 4 more.  Some of my favorites, like uni and hotate were so well done.  But I also enjoyed trying something different like Japanese barracuda.  Wasn't aware I could be one level up from barracuda on the food chain, but I enjoyed it anyway. And it didn't taste any more fierce than weaklings like salmon or mackerel.
author: Candice B.

description: straightforward authentic Japanese dining experience...do not hesitate to miss this. high end amazing sushi and Japanese cuisine period.
author: Michael K.

description:
If you like fine dining and know your sushi then this a must try for you! I meant sushi, and not maki, let's be clear on that ;)

I was in the city for a day and happened to discover this little corner. They are a very private and small dine in place, I would describe it as quaint and quiet. They have only 4 tables and a small sushi bar. My favorite place is the sushi bar since you can observe the chefs making these delicious delicacies. 

So go ahead, it's completely worth the splurge!
author: EM L.

description: Might be the best sushi spot in the city if price is not of a concern.  Ate the Omakase special there are few months ago and was in sushi heaven from start to finish.  We had the usual sushi pieces as you would expect from most sushi bars.  In my opinion the rice in the sushi is the best I have had in SF.  The rice had a great balance of firmness while not feeling too hard, while have the right amount of vinegar.  The price is on the higher side that you would pay in SF, but if you are a sushi lover, then I would highly recommend this place.
author: Joe P.

description:
The service was great--absolutely no complaints! 
The hostess who greeted us was very friendly and welcoming while the rest of the staff was kind and helpful. We sat at the sushi counter and had a pleasant conversation with one of the sushi chefs. 

Everything was perfectly executed.

Thank you so much for a wonderful evening!
author: J H.

description:
Get the omakase and let the good times roll. Except without rolls, because Ijji serves delicious nigiri and sashimi expertly prepared. Small room with eight or so seats at the bar and a handful of small tables. I grabbed a couple appetizers first; one of which was the best octopus in recent memory. Then I ate my weight in nigiri, loving each one. Finished with some tamago atsuyaki so rich that I want an entire one for my next birthday cake.

I'm not someone who knows anything about sake yet, so I cannot speak to their selection. Asahi on tap worked well enough for me.

Loved it & l shall return.
author: bill f.

description:
I don't think I've ever felt inspired or enlightened at a restaurant before until dining here. The ambience and decor at this place is incredibly calming and zen, but remains friendly and accessible at the same time. There are only a few tables and bar seats available, so it's really intimate. Service is great and the staff are knowledgable.

Our group did the omakase tasting and it was nothing short of incredible. The presentation is simple and the fish (everything flown in from Japan!) is flavorful and paired perfectly with their vinegared rice and flavor cues. 

Standout nigiri for me were the uni, black sea bass and Japanese horse mackerel. As far as starters, the baby octopus was awesome and so was the chawanmushi.
author: Narek A.

description: Amazing food quality, service, and interior. I loved everything I had but my favorites are unagi,  toros (o-toro, chu-toro), and uni. Highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Diana Soyeon B.

description: Aki-san, the chef here moved from maruya. I'm a big fan of his cooking so when he moved I found out about this place and made a reservation right away. For those familiar w maruya, ijji is an even better version of it. Smaller, homier, cleaner interior. Smaller portions (omakase is 8 pcs) and more flexibility with how much you want to eat. Fewer cooked dishes since the kitchen is quite small, but the appetizers are excellent. Very unique list of sake collection. Would suggest ordering a few apps, omakase and adding a few pieces as you go, based on how hungry you feel. The homemade matcha icecream w red bean topping dessert is not sweet and made just right!
author: G T.

description: Ijji lives up to its name, which when translated means uncompromising.  Everything about this place is done thoughtfully and with craft.  The sushi is amazing, even fish that normally gives me pause was delicious.  The interior is Japanese and understated with custom wood cabinetry and counters.  This place takes sushi up to a new level.  I can no longer eat at my local sushi spot.
author: Gisela S.

description:
4 Stars rounded up. 
Ijji describes itself as a neighborhood Sushiya and they completely are. The service was prompt and amiable and never once did I as a solo diner feel uncomfortable. 

I first visited last year in February and wanted to try their new omakase only menu and it is a definite improvement compared to last year. The new price gives them a lot more structure and attention to detail/quality that it was missing from last year. The new price is $135 for 13 pieces of nigiri and ~4 tsumami, along with red miso soup and dessert. This is a VERY reasonable price when you compare how many pieces you get plus tsumami compared to other places. 

Ijji uses a combination of three different vinegars in their rice; shirazu (white), akazu (red), and an aged akazu (red). While it was an interesting combination I felt like its mixture made it lack an identity that didn't completely compliment the fish itself. Unfortunately, the rice was slightly cold and a little overcooked :(. 

To summarize their fish; of course its fresh, no sinew and everything of top quality. As for garnishes its all pretty traditional, which is good! A blowtorch was only used on one piece and their seasoning was mostly their own house made soy sauce (a tad salty), yuzu, and seaweed salt. At the beginning of the nigiri course the main chef whom I had the pleasure of being served by said that we could adjust the seasonings (wasabi/soy sauce) according to our tastes. I feel like this openness isn't found in other Sushiyas due to a fear of the chef being a sushi-nazi. Highlights included a secret menu ankimo braised in their soy sauce and dashi, hokkaido sea scallop half with seaweed salt and soy sauce, santa barbara and hokkaido uni together, braised octopus, and kama toro. The ankimo was EXTREMELY tender and flavorful, completely beating Sasaki's chalky and firm ankimo. The sea scallop was extremely fresh maintaining its firmness and succulent sweetness juxtaposed by the saltiness of soy and salt. The other pieces were definitely solid and highlighted the silver-skinned fish predominant in the winter season. 
Their ala carte menu is also fairly small, most of it repeats of what was in the omakase, aside from ikura, kama toro, and hotaru ika to name a few. No wagyu for those wondering. 

Service wise this place gets a 5/5. The chefs and waiter/waitress were all very friendly. The chefs explained aspects of the fish such as wild vs farmed, different fishes caught in the season, and their cooking process for some of their dishes. They were also extremely open to answering questions. As for service I never felt pressured with time or ordering more drinks. As for their alcohol menu they have the standard Japanese beers available (Hitachino, Coedo, Echigo, Suntory), some wines, and an OK sake list. Their choice of sake leaned toward tokubetsu and Ginjos, which I feel compliments their aesthetic as a neighborhood Sushiya. 

Overall I don't think Ijji compares with other places in terms of creative flavor combinations, an expansive sake list,  or a huge ala carte menu, but it does what it does great. It focuses on what is seasonally available and is definitely a prized neighborhood Sushiya. The ambiance and service are definitely standouts and they are a solid choice for a more laid back option.
author: Chad S.

description:
We shared our anniversary night at Ijji.  We experienced wonderful service at every step.  The restaurant is tiny, but beautiful updated.  On the night we enjoyed dinner at Ijji, they had run out of a few items.  Fortunately, the server told us in the beginning.  We ordered the omakase.  Two appetizers were served, one asparagus, and the other conch.  Both were lively and full of rich flavor.  Nigiri included amberjack, octopus, medium fatty toro, horse mackerel, sea bream, halibut, salmon roe, Arctic char, belt fish, and clam.  The stars were the amberjack, toro, and sea bream.

In addition we had the snow crab, which is fabulous, and the A5 beef nigiri which is great but maybe not worth the money relative to the other nigiri.

Each course was timed to maximize the experience.  A course would explore texture and unique favors as complements to the fish.

You get what you pay for here.  Ijji is pricey as expected, but well worth the money.
author: Justin D.

description: Thanks Ben for the great suggestion. We walked in on the later side and had a drink at the Page for about 20 minutes until our bar seats were ready. I'm so happy we opted for the bar; the lighting was perfect creating a movie-like setting watching the three sushi chefs work their magic. There is a fourth chef that stands in back right in support, but he sort of just hangs out there the whole night. We took the classic nigiri omakase and every single piece was perfect; each bite was tender, no connective tissue or other issues. Highlights included the fire squid, which is only in season for about 6 weeks each spring, the Hokkaido uni (smaller and denser than it's California counterpart) and the toro, which was order separately. Also props for their rendition of ankimo which had the liver intact versus the pate form found everywhere else I've eaten. The chefs were quiet but eager to educate with any question I had about the fish, it's origin or how to eat it properly. The sake menu is extensive and I'd suggest trying by the glass versus a bottle so you may try the wide variety-- as always, stay dry, my friends.
author: Brian J.

description:
Just ridiculous.  Hard to call it your neighborhood sushi joint when I'd cross town to eat there...good thing I only need to walk a block.

If you're in the neighborhood check it out before everyone finds out about this place.  if you live outside the neighborhood...just go when I'm not going.  

There are literally only 17 seats.
author: Chris D.

description:
Definitely one of my new favorite sushi spots in the city. Very traditional in its approach, a quiet environment, and the fish is fresh - you feel like you're at a local joint in Japan. The price was standard omakase prices, and way cheaper than Kusakabe. It's a tiny gem of a spot. 

Highly recommend the omakase if it's your 1st time. My favorites were naturally the a la carte ordering of the toro and the seared wagyu beef. 

The staff is nice. Wait was a bit longer than anticipated (we had reservations), and there wasn't anywhere to stand without being in the way. I'd definitely go back.
author: Tammy H.

description:
I think its safe to say, best sushi in SF. My husband and I personally thought it was better than Saru. Love the décor of this place, very reminiscent of Japan. Simple, clean and minimal. I feel that all sushi places need to be this way. 

We went with the omakase and I would highly suggest you do the same. Chef's selection changes so we trust they picked the best fish for us. We didn't have one bad piece, I loved every bite we had. The highlight would be the Toro, oh my goodness, I haven't had such good Toro since Japan and this only made my desire to go back to Japan even stronger. The Uni was also a two thumbs up!

Highly suggest making reservations when you go. We walked in right when it opened so they had seats available but were put on a time limit since they needed the table for upcoming reservation. 

GO, GET YOUR SUSHI ON.
author: Nho C.

description: Great fish. Great service. Simple beautiful interior. What more are you looking for?
author: Uyen Uyen T.

description:
We found out about this through a friend of mine who is an omakase lover. 
I know there are many solid places to have omakase at in the Bay Area (Kusakabe, Omakase, Maruyama), but this place was spot on. 
The restaurant is small and intimate, only seating 16 customers. 
As soon as we entered through their wooden door, we were welcomed by the sushi chefs and hostess. I had made a reservation through open table a few weeks prior (credit card is required to reserve your spot) and she checked me in and lead us to the sushi bar. 
I usually like sitting at the sushi bar for omakase because I love watching the chefs prepare the fish and talk with them. After taking a quick look at the menu we were ready to order. Our server was quick to realize and rushed right over. He was very attentive. 
We went with the omakase selection with 13 pieces & starter. 
As each piece of fish was laid in front of us, the chef gave us a background of each. 
He was very knowledgable and kind in answering all of our questions. 
The fish was very fresh in taste and otoro melted in my mouth (which I could eat a million pieces of) 
Every bite was a trip back to Tokyo. 
We ended our tasting with an order of satsuma beef nigiri which was amazing on its own. 
It was $15 for one piece, but definitely worth it. 
Overall, our experience at Ijji's was beyond what we had expected and we will be back very soon!
author: Samantha Y.

description: Excellent sushi  place for omakase. Quality comparable to the best in Tokyo. So glad it's walking distance.....
author: Gilbert L.

description:
We had a lovely dinner here!  We did the omakase at the bar.  It was a bit odd in that the omakase price was listed as MP.  All other restaurants we have been to state their set price.  Maybe their omakase changes with each person so hard to set a firm price though we were not really asked what we wanted, it seemed more set.  

That being said, we enjoyed all the fish.  Their ikura btw was really good! You could tell it was fresh and homemade with big eggs that popped in your mouth!  No gumminess.  My favorite was their hotate, scallop at $6.  I had to do that one twice! Very sweet!  They said it was live from Japan.  I think though what they consider live and what I consider live maybe 2 different things.  I expect live to be in the shell minutes before served.  I think, and I may be wrong, but I think they mean never frozen.  That being said, it still was excellent!  

The wagyu we ordered after the omakase at $13 a piece was the only nigiri that did not meet expectations.  Not bad, but not great either.  I find the quality really varies place to place with most places not serving A5 that is worth the price.  For $13 for a skinny little piece of beef, it best be a very tasty skinny piece!!!  LOL.  After you have had the good stuff, it can be disappointing.

We also really enjoyed our sushi chef, David.  He was most agreeable.  Very chatty and informative.  There were 2 waitresses both of whom really set a friendly atmosphere.  We interacted a lot with Katie and she was a real delight.  Such good waitstaff is worth their weight in gold!!

I was a bit apprehensive when David pulled out a plate of precut fish for our omakase from under the counter.  Though I think it must have been cut fairly recently since the flavor was still good.  We were the 1st customers and with a slow beginning before they got busy, they had plenty of time to cut the fish as needed instead of precutting it.  As the night went on, it seemed that only 1 chef did the cutting and passed the cut fish to the other chefs.  They had plenty of help with 4 sushi chef always behind the counter for such a small restaurant. 

We would definitely frequent this restaurant if we lived nearby.  The quality at Ijji is solid! 

I suspect that with repeated visits, we would discover a lot of special touches unique to Ijji.   If we lived nearby, we would enjoy discovering them all!! 

Parking is hit or miss it appeared.  We were lucky to find a space a block and a half away though I could see where it could be an issue.
author: Kell M.

description: Everything was excellent. Ordered the omakase and was very impressed with the quality. Wako is probably what I consider the best sushi in SF and this definitely comes close.
author: P K.

description:
This is the best nigiri Omakase in San Francisco.   The service was perfect for what you would expect from a michelin star sushi restaurant.  One part of this service means about food restrictions or dislikes prior to the start of the dinner service.   This is expensive and bordering on overpriced as our tab for two people with drinks was $500.   Still worth it.

Special mention for the Uni which was perfect.
author: william c.

description:
They've done a great job with the design of this new restaurant. A good balance between peaceful and hip leads to a great atmosphere in which to enjoy their fresh nigiri.

I started with the Asari Akadashi (red miso with manila clams) -- really tasty. Then moved on to nigiri, ordering 13 pieces. My favorites were the Negitoro (fatty tuna with green onions), Umi Masu (ocean trout), Shoyu Ikura (soy sauce marinated salmon roe), and the Muki Hotate (live scallop) -- all were really well executed and fresh tasting.

I finished off with a piece of the Tamago Atsuyaki (japanese omelet), which was so delicious and cake-like with a subtle sweetness that it easily acted as dessert!

My only critique of the food was that the Uni was served a bit cold for my liking.

Don't expect rolls and soy sauce here! This is a nigiri-focused restaurant, and the pieces are seasoned as the chefs intend them to be eaten to bring out the flavor of the fish.

Ijji is a great addition to the neighborhood and city, and I'll definitely be back... though maybe not as frequently as I'd like, given the price. (Red Miso + 13 pieces + 1 Hitachino beer = $93 before tax and tip)
author: Scott H.

description: This place is really high quality. The service is outstanding, probably the best service I've ever had. The food is also very good.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: Easily the most amazing sushi I've ever had. My first dive into omakase was a successful one and I recommend everyone to try it!
author: Dimitriy N.

description: Excellent all around. Yes, it is expensive and yes you could find something to quibble about if you really wanted to. But, you'd only be diminishing your own experience at that point. This is definitely one of the best sushi places in the city right now and number one on my revisit list.
author: Joseph S.

description: Came here with another couple for the omakase dinner.  We sat at a table and you don't quite get the full experience.  It was good but I've also had better, hate to say.  Definitely fresh fish...my hunt continues for my favorite sushi restaurant.
author: Meredith K.

description: Came here on our anniversary dinner and we ordered Omakase and it was was great! The fish was fresh and served at the right temperature. The selection could be larger though because we had to order additional items after the omakase course was complete. Bill for 2 people ended up being $225 with one alcoholic beverage.
author: Allen T.

description: Ijji serves up the best freshest fish in the city! We tried Kusakabe before and spent a crazy amount for two.  We thought food here was even better for about half the price!!!  I recommend sitting at the bar to get the full experience. We really enjoyed talking to master chef Ken and learning about the best tasting fish we ever had.  Can't wait to return!!!
author: Robert L.

description: Wonderful sushi. Amazing service from front hostess to the chefs. The chefs are all so wonderful to chat with. Really try to sit at the bar if possible - it's amazing watching them work. A good restaurant is not just a meal but an experience. I came for my birthday and they really made me feel special. I don't think I can ever forget this night and am so excited to come back in the future to try new fresh fish flown in from Japan. We got the omakase - the fish was all delicious and fresh - not a single bad sushi. I loved asking the chefs about the background of the fish and really learning from them.  I could go on and on and tell you what fish was good, but really it will depend on when you go and what's fresh.  I can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Jenny W.

description: Incredibly rude, arrogant service. I went in for a table and was greeted with a condescending hostess and mediocre establishment. The whole scene turned me off. I want to see new establishments on divis but this place is all attitude.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Dont know why people are praising this place. Had a very high expectation based on yelp reviews and foodie articles but I guess this is what you get with $80-90 in SF omakase scene. Venue was nice.
author: Ren N.

description: Fancy sushi alert. Fresh fish. Super simple. Prepared perfectly. Delicious. Great service.
author: Stephanie R.

description: I give this place a 3.5 star.  The service was great, the sushi was decent but did not wow me.  I recognize one of the guys from Saru.  A little better quality than saru, but also a little more expensive.  The highlight was the firefly squid. If you were to start with sushi this would be a good place to start and try, should be good first experience with omakase.
author: Richard M.

description: One if the best sushi experiences I have had. We sat at the counter and ordered the omakase. Fantastic cuts, with fish we had not tried before. We especially likes the Japanese beltfish, the anago, and the hirame. We ordered a bottle of organic junmai, I believe. It was the only one listed as organic on the menu. It was crisp but not too dry. The restaurant is not cheap, but it was worth it. I'd definitely visit again.
author: Anthony J.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant in the city. The card is simple. A few appetizers and a lot of sushi. Most come with their own glaze and topping. Presentation is outstanding and the it all taste great. Especially liked the (charred) barracuda and the fatty tuna. Highly recommended! But make a reservation before coming because the place is tiny.
author: Ruben K.

description: This is another omakase only restaurant ($135/person, will be $145 beginning July 1, 2017) with no visible sign, only a menu on the door, on Haight and Page streets.  Wife and I made reservation for 6 PM, which is necessary for seating at the sushi bar. We had made a reservation for 6:15 PM through Open Table requesting sushi bar, and Ijji called me and stated that to be seated at the sushi bar, the reservations had to be changed to 6 PM.    It was a warm evening, and we were served with cold towels and a cold tea, which were welcome.  The air conditioning, however, was not quite adequate.  There were three sushi chefs and behind them were stations manned by other workers.  This is a small restaurant with several tables and the sushi bar.  We were served a number of small appetizers including uni and other delicacies which were quite fresh and attractive.  The sushi was fresh, delicious, and the rise was just the right temperature and just the right amount.  It seemed that slight searing of the sushi fish was done rather frequently with a torch. The chef was quite friendly and personable, and the service was impeccable.  They serve sake, wine, and beer; wife had a glass of sauvignon blanc and I had the rice beer, which was just right for the warm day.  This is an intimate restaurant with a serene atmosphere, and we enjoyed our dinner thoroughly.  This restaurant is favorably comparable to Kinjo, and almost to Kusakabe.
author: Hoyle L.

description: Ijji was awesome. I can honestly say that it was probably the top 2 best sushi experiences I've ever had. Everything I had was to perfection. We had the omakase and every piece was to die for. From the toro to the home made green tea ice cream. I have been telling everyone about this place and am planning to go back again soon.
author: Daniel C.

description: We had a great time at Ijji Sushi last night. Definitely make sure you sit at the bar, as half the fun is watching the sushi chefs prepare the nigiri. The omakase was delicious and overall a really fun experience. Each piece was so different from the last, and they were all created with such meticulous attention to detail. We actually had the owner preparing our food for us, which was extra cool. The chefs are all personable and happy to chat. A little pricey but definitely worth it, especially for a special occasion.
author: Rachel M.

description: Don't even know where to start.  We had their omakase and on top of that we had couple order of the , Chawamushi, Japanese uni and Japanese Tamago.  Uni and Tamago definitely stand out among all the other dishes.  Tamago is the Japanese egg, it took the chef 4 hours to prepare the dish.  It doesn't taste like egg at all instead a very moist 1000 layer cake.  The Japanese uni is much smaller than the American ones.  It's sweeter and more soft with it's texture.  Definitely one of the best sushi restaurant in San Francisco.  Services was above and beyond.  The Japanese server was very attentive and also professional, I stopped counting how many times they change our dishes and tea cups.  The reservation is still relatively easy to make, try it before it gets busy or more pricey.   =)
author: Jade P.

description: The dining experience is nothing short of transcendent! Whether you go with the chef's Omakase preset or opt for freestyle, you won't be disappointed. Our server took plenty of time to orient each person in our party to each piece they ordered -- he was superbly informative and polite to a fault. Each round was an event. The flavors were subtle, layered and sophisticated. My favorite had to be the satsuma beef (I know...how can a sushi place manage to make the cow hold its own with the fish). Not to undersell the various seafood offerings -- the chu toro bluefin and sakura masu cherry salmon were also exquisite. We paired the meal with a better sake and a few uncommon Japanese beers. A well-rounded evening at Ijji, while a tad spendy, will leave you knowing how quality sushi can and should be enjoyed.
author: Tony A.

description: Loved all the nigiri served as Omakase. All the fish, scallop, sea urchin, and meat were fresh and crazy tasty. Worth visiting. I don't live here but wanna visit here again. The chef was also great!! Thank you!!!
author: Makiko Y.

description:
What an INCREDIBLE experience it was! I felt as if I was visiting a high-end Japanese restaurant back in Japan.  Everything about them was top-notch.

For sushi, we initially ordered Omakase (chef's menu).  When it's done, we added 3 pieces and Tamago (egg) that our amazing chef recommended.  There was nothing that was "just ok."  Every single sushi was work of art.  It was beautiful to detail and tasted absolutely fantastic.  My friend and I kept nodding for each sushi as we enjoyed several stages of tastes changing in our mouths.  I felt my brain melting...

The style of their sushi is not the one you put soy sauce on your own.  Chef does all the work, and you eat them as they are presented.  Ijji sushi suggests customers to use their fingers for sushi instead of chopsticks.  Sushi actually tastes better eating that way because we can keep the perfect condition of sushi until we put it into mouth.

Their sake was incredible too.  The list is not big, but they've got really good ones. We ordered a bottle of Konteki Daiginjo (Tears of Dawn) which I never heard of before.  It was ABSOLUTELY delicious and perfect for sushi.  I also like their idea that they use a wine glass for sake.  We got to enjoy subtle aroma drinking that way more than drinking from a regular sake glass/cup.

Service was excellent.  Everybody was super serious about providing great dining experience for customers.  Our service person was very attentive and professional.  He actually looked casual but his service was formal, which I liked a lot.  One of examples was that every time my glass became empty, he showed up right away but asked me if I'd like more before he actually poured sake for me.  And every time we asked him something, he said "certainly" instead of "absolutely".  

Appetizer was also delicious.  We ordered Chawan-mushi (savory egg custard), Akadashi (clam miso soup) and Kani Sunomono (Cucumbers and crab in vinegar broth) and loved them all.

I highly recommend to make a reservation so you can sit at sushi bar.
author: Akiko O.

description: I took a chance it was incredible could have been highlight of my trip. My girlfriend and I still are on debate but this place was amazing. The fish was incredibly fresh and the service was top notch. Didn't expect to have such a wonderful experience. Was not pretentious at all if you have a question just ask.
author: Doug K.

description: What a gem!  Incredibly top notch sushi.  I went with my coworker who grew up in Japan, and she and I agreed it was among the best sushi we've ever tasted.  Each piece of nigiri had so much thought, care, and attention to every detail.  Each piece was like a story in my mouth, with several phases of deliciousness.  The non-sushi items on the menu were also excellent.  The service was fantastic and professional.  I'll be back as much as I can!
author: Todd R.

description: I think I'd have been kicked out if I'd asked for soy sauce or wasabi, but I found everything really bland.  $190 (with tip) for two people for 10 very small pieces of fish each, no drinks. Pleasant service.
author: Lizbeth S.

description: I'm a fan of Saru so I was very excited to try Ijji. With so many omakase restaurants opening recently, it's nice that you can choose what you want to eat. Unfortunately, the experience was very disappointing! I'm use to spending $$$ for top quality sushi but Ijji did not meet my expectations. The quality of the fish was not very high and the prices are outrageously expensive. I would recommend going to Saru, where the prices are lower and the quality is just the same, if not, better. One plus is that you can make reservations.
author: Q C.

description: Much better than Kusakabe. You don't have to get Omakase before you can order from the a la carte menu. All the fish was amazing. The A5, toro, and uni were amazing.
author: nikkita l.

description: Amazing Omakase - delicate flavours and the freshest fish all the way from Japan. I'd recommend the Omakase if you can because we tried fish that we would not normally have ordered and they were the best dishes - snapper, mackerel, scallop. Everything was perfectly seasoned and the wine was well thought out. I'm a regular at Sushi Ota and have been to all the good Japanese places in SF - I'd say this is the best of the best. Great atmosphere and nice people too. Could not recommend more highly.
author: Natalie M.

description: I lived in Japan and I've been searching for an authentic Japanese sushi restaurant -- in terms of atmosphere, service, and, especially, the preparation and taste of the food -- ever since I've been back in the States. I finally found it. Ijji makes the grade on all fronts. This is the best sushi I've tasted outside of Japan, period, and I've tried plenty. The staff and chefs are outstanding and very friendly as well. I only wish it wasn't so small, even though I really like the intimate atmosphere, because once the word gets around it's going to be very hard to get in.
author: Michael L.

description:
Haven't been there yet, it's on our list, but for almost 40 years I have lived directly above the SARU space on 24th St. It was one of the first Sushi restaurants in the city, I was and still am  friends with the original owners, Fussae (not sure if she's still with us) and Yoshi, and then Tama and Hiroko. Late in the evening/morning that Tama opened we were out in the back yard, flying on Sake and howling at the moon.
I witnessed on a daily basis the effort and dedication that Billy and Katy put into creating the SARU space. With the support of their staff they have established an excellent and successful business, sometimes I have to push my way through the line so I can get to my rent controlled front door. Now that I'm a retired and impoverished RN I can't afford to eat out any more that often, but I can sit on the back stairs with a glass of wine and a bowl of home grown and inhale the aromas. I can attest to the quality of the food at SARU and have no reason to think that IJJI won't be another step up the ladder in Billy's quest for a Michelin. Update anon, maybe after my next SSI cheque and the bills are paid.
author: Patrick M.

description: My boyfriend and I found Ijji Sushi on yelp and decided to go there for our anniversary dinner. The chefs were all very friendly and worked hard to make sure that the sushi was prepared to perfection. We both ordered the omakase and every piece of sushi that we received was absolutely delicious. The servers were very prompt about filling water and checking in throughout the meal to make sure everything was going alright. If you want delicious sushi and a great atmosphere, this is the place to go. Make sure to make a reservation in advance to ensure your seat. Ask to sit at the bar if it is available. It is well worth the price!
author: Rachel R.

description: Best sushi in the bay. Sit at the bar and enjoy the spectacle. Staff explains all the items very well. Discipline shows in service. Worth every penny. Had 15 pieces plus egg custard to start and green tea ice cream to finish.
author: Mark S.

description: Had a lovely evening at Ijji. The space is beautiful and traditional- lots of wood and minimalist decor. Hands down my favorite atmosphere for a sushi spot. Although this really can't be called a sushi spot, they focus on nigiri and sashimi, and it's stellar! The chefs and staff are incredibly friendly and make you feel very welcome. Overall incredible nigiri, warm and inviting atmosphere and very friendly staff. I would certainly recommend to anyone looking to step up their sushi game :)
author: Fiona S.

description: What to know: no rolls, strictly nigiri, seasonal menu, eaten right to left with your fingers (complete with finger towels!). There is a-lot of care and attention paid to the details; and what delicious details they are. This isn't what has become passed off as sushi, and not be for everyone's palate, but it's clear that ijji is marching to a different drummer. If the word eclectic can be used to describe sushi cuisine, this surely would fit this restaurant.
author: David T.
